title: SO MUCH FUN
text: Bought one for my daughter and one for my husband for Christmas. They LOVE it. It is great for the experienced and for the beginning pilot. The battery life is reasonable and the graphics on the camera are great!. With a tap of a button on the remote you can control the camera and video taking feature. We love seeing the videos they take. Extremely durable. Color coded LED lights make this fun to fly at night. Its a scaled down version of the DJI. Six axis gyros make this very stable. After posting some pics and videos on Facebook all my husbands friends are looking to get one for themselves. You can't beat the price on such a great toy. Only complaint... We wish we had another battery so they don't have to wait (75 minutes) for the fun to continue.

text:
I'm loving this thing... I've been flying it in the living room low and slow until I get the hang of it. I did take it outside once so far, but it was a little too windy and this thing is really light weight.
One thing I will mention that's well worth the money, is buying the extra batteries and charger, plus the accessory pack with the different color blades, landing gear, prop guards and motors. (cheap.. $29 bucks for everything) I put different color blades on the front forward 2 rotors so I could easily see which way the front is facing. It helps extremely when the drone is flying back towards you and everything is backwards when controlling it.

title: So incredibly tough and forgiving... not to mention FUN.
text:
After getting an X12 over Christmas, and having an absolute blast crashing into everything while learning to fly indoors, I decided it was time to see what it was like outside. Flying an X12 outside left something to be desired, so I began researching to figure out what might fit the bill. After reading MANY reviews and watching a ton of videos, I chose the X5c. It fit my budget, and I got the impression that it truly was a great quad to learn on.

Well, after only a few short months of owning it I can say with certainty that the X5 has certainly held up its end of the bargain, and then some. I say "X5", and not X5"c", because the camera that comes with this thing is pretty lame. The angle (or field of vision, if you prefer) is very narrow. And I don't know if this is simply an issue with Macs, but I had to reformat the SD-card all the time- simply deleting files didn't work. Otherwise, the camera would believe that there wasn't enough space on the card and wouldn't record. So, this made it very easy for me to make the decision to jettison the camera all together, and just let this bird fly free. And I didn't stop there... the feet were no longer necessary either, so away they went too. The prop guards? Never even bothered attaching them to begin with. Flying this thing was kinda fun before getting rid of that stuff, but it became much more fun without the extra baggage.

From the beginning, I chose to learn on "advanced mode", just because it was faster, more responsive, and more challenging. However, I was by no means "advanced" at flying these things. The first time I took it anyplace that wasn't my tiny front yard, I took it to a local park and flew it up kinda high. Well, then I experienced that common thing where you kinda get disoriented with where the quad is in relation to nearby trees, and somehow I flew it into some woods with it impacting the first few branches at around 50 feet. Somehow, by some miracle, the thing didn't get hung up in any of those branches- I'm attributing that to the fact that it was still winter time (not many leaves to help hold it there)... so, where does it ultimately land? Where else, than in a creek? Yup! Brand new lil quad... in the creek. I just took a big deep breath and hung my head when I realized this. Somehow the thing was still on when I fished it out (it never completely submerged- landed in shallow area). I immediately turned it off and removed the battery before shaking it out best I could. Then I brought it home, opened it up, and placed it on the floor about a foot away from a space heater to allow it to dry out for the rest of the day. The next morning, I put everything back together, popped the recharged battery back in, and everything worked perfectly. From then on, I became much more careful about flying at any sort of altitude that included potential trees... and creeks, for that matter. It also didn't take me long to see the need for more batteries. I bought one of the packages available here on Amazon, where it provides you with four batteries and a 4x1 charger to charge them all simultaneously. I also bought to extra batteries before getting the 4x1. So, now that I have 7 batteries, I find myself not only enjoying the thing more, personally, I also have found more time to teach others how to fly it.

O, and before I forget... another sad, yet awesome, thing that happened: I was on my way to go begin my marathon of marathon study sessions for finals when I stopped by at a nearby church to catch about 10 minutes of flight time. I parked in a different area than usual so that I could see what range I could accomplish, and then flew it back with more altitude and speed than I'd intended.... well, I didn't turn fast enough and right behind me was a nice tree waiting to catch the quad. It got stuck at probably 40 feet up. I found various things laying around to throw at it, and even when I hit it with a lightweight block of wood, the thing still didn't budge. I climbed as high as I could, but the branches became too thin and there was no one around to spot me if I fell. Not worth it. So, I just had to let it be. I thought to myself... o well, you need to study anyway. This thing was obviously only meant to be an ill-fated distraction. So I went on my way and decided that I'd re-evaluate the situation only after I'd gotten through at least half of the material I needed to cover. So, a week and several thunderstorms later, I returned to the scene to find the quad stil sitting up in the tree looking all happy. I devised a telescoping "pushstick" made out of an 8' cardboard tube and some quarter round. I tied a rope to it, climbed the tree as high as I could, and then managed to push the quad out of the tree after extending the "pushstick" to a length of almost 20 feet. Took the quad home, opened it up, and it was bone dry and with no signs of rust of weathering. I put it all back together, and it worked. No problems at all. It's amazing.

I've crashed this thing into everything except for myself or other people. I've let my dog chase it, and eventually she even got ahold of it. Still, the quad survives. It slammed into a road sign at full speed earlier today. It survives. I've put this thing through tons of punishment, and thus far, the only thing I've needed to replace is two of those tiny cogs/gears at the bottom of the motor (the ones that engage with the larger gears that actually spin the props). These smaller gears seem to have a tendency to slip over time, and then they fall off. I've gotten into the habit of performing a little flight check before each flight, and confirming that those are properly seated seems to have made a big difference. Still, I have extras now. In anticipation of eventually burning out a motor, I also went ahead and purchased an extra CW and CCW motor. The nice thing about the prospect of changing out the motors is that the new ones have a metal gear that seems like it won't slip like the little plastic ones do. I dunno; we'll see.

I know I'll eventually destroy this thing, but OMG it blows my mind how much it's been through and is still going strong. I'd post a picture of how beat up it is, but I'm afraid it wouldn't really do it justice. It's scratched all over, one of the props was bent and then reshapaned before getting chewed on by my friend's cat. Still, the quad survives...

Once I finally burn out a motor or somehow destroy this thing, I'll update my review to let you know how it goes. Overall, I'm getting a lot of good times out of it. Still learning new ways to enjoy it. Definitely the start of a new hobby.

title: ... write too many reviews but after having so much fun with this inexpensive but capable drone
text:
I don't write too many reviews but after having so much fun with this inexpensive but capable drone, I felt compelled to. First off, I am a 51 one year old man who does not play video games, so using the remote control is not second nature like it may be for someone who grew up playing video games. It took a little while to learn, about 20 minutes of indoor flying (garage) before I felt comfortable enough to take it out. Once outside this thing really moves and can easily be taken away in the wind. Keep it low at first. It is durable. I have crashed it too many times to count on concrete and the only issue was, I have lost 2 lenses that go over the LED lights. No biggie, a little packing taped now protects the lights and a red marker lets me know where the front of the drone is. I see some part kits for 30 bucks, but for 40 you may as well get another complete drone.

If you are going to move up, this is a great learning drone. If you want to have some fun, spend no more, this is well worth the 40 dollars.

title: 2nd drone 2nd lower left motor died
text: I like this quadcopter but the lower left motor for the second time has failed. I returned the first one no problem and bought another and the motor failed again. I don't think I'll buy this brand again because of this problem. You can buy rep,a event motors cheap but they aren't plug and play replacements. The motor wires have to be unsoldered then re-soldered to the circuit board which I'm not going to want to have to do when the warranty expires.

title: Great learner drone...
text: I'm still learning to control this thing but I'm having fun trying. It's pretty stable in flight and not the fastest but it's great for any noobs. Bought a spare parts kit and it was inexpensive so I'm not scared to crash this drone.

title: Love it!
text: Fits perfectly and I love the texture of the keyboard. I thought it would be/feel cheap, but it doesn't.

title: Great beginner / low budget quadcopter
text:
We bought the Syma X5C for my 10 year old son for Christmas and he loves it. It's a great entry-level quadcopter. As with anything like this, there is a little bit of a learning curve but any kid with decent hand-eye coordination will be able to pick it up quickly.
While it's not indestructible, it is very durable. We've crashed it many times with no damage. One extra set of four propellersis included but we haven't had to use them - yet.
One of the greatest features of this quadcopter is that replacement parts are inexpensive and easy to find (and I don't mean just the propellers - virtually every part can be purchased separately). We have had to replace one motor which wasn't difficult - although it did require a little patience and basic soldering skills.
Battery life is a limitation. Average flight time on the included 500mAh battery is in the 10 minute range and charge time is in the 90 minute range. I would definitely recommend buying multiple batteries (there is a nice little set of 5 700mAh batteries and gang charger (charges all of them at one time) available here on Amazon - get it.
The video from the camera is really pretty good. We enjoy going home and watching the videos from our flights.
While it may seem a bit counter-intuitive, if you're going to be flying around trees leave the propeller guards off - they are what tends to get snagged in trees.

Overall - this is a great little beginner quadcopter and I can definitely recommend it.

title: Undoubtedly one of best beginner drones on the market for under $50
text: Undoubtedly one of best beginner drones on the market for under $50! Very stable flight characteristics. Outdoor flying was possible after only 2 days of indoor practice with the control transmitter. Flight time is somewhat brief (6-8 minutes) so ordering extra batteries and charger is a must. I bought this drone as a trainer before graduating to a DJI Phantom but will probably fly this drone on a regular basis anyway. Camera quality (still photos and video) are good quality considering this little drone does not have a gimble. Transmitter range meets the new FAA LOS requirements of 450 feet with excellent signal control.

title: I love it. Best for the price.
text: Excellent. Give it a week of practice and you'll be good at it. Just use common sence when you start flying. Stay away from houses, trees and wires. Don't fly on windy days. Go ahead and purposely crash the drone instead of letting it get away from you if the wind starts to carry it away. Just go very gentle on the controls, just like in a car, over correcting is what will cause the crash more often than not.

title: Great beginner drone!
text:
I got this as a fun way to spend my time on the beach. This was cheap enough and had an included camera so I went for it - not expecting much. Holy crap is this thing fun. One of the best investments I made. It flies really well - and has some cool features like doing barrel rolls and having options for low and high speed.

This thing was surviging on the beach with relatively high winds - i was impressed. Of course I lost control of it several times - but it held up through the crashes and sand.

Taking images and videos is a pain on this thing - it is hard to tell when its on or not. Also you have to turn off the camera first before turningn the drone off or else the data will become corrupted. Further, the image and video quality is somewhat shitty. The video - when the drone is stabilized - is OK but there is no gyro or stabilizer for the camera so do not expect much.

If you are looking to fly a drone for the first time this one is great - if you want to dish out extra dough look for drones that have a larger range (100m).

Just by analyzing my roof and having the roofers fix thier mistakes, this product has paid for itself. I WANT ANOTHER ONE!

title: The absolute best $50 I have ever spent on a toy
text:
The absolute best $50 I have ever spent on a toy. I was only a little curious in drones when I bought this guy. When I received it in the mail I was pretty excited. I unboxed it and I was flying 15 minutes later. Now I am addicted. I almost wish I didn't buy because now it's all I want to do. My lawn hasn't been mowed since I received this thing. I'm waiting to see if I come home to a note on my door from the town telling me to mow my lawn.

With all the functions on this thing, it took me a little getting used to. But after a few hours(and alot of crashes) I got the hang of it.

Two bits of advise: 1. buy spare parts, like batteries and props.
2. Be responsible and fly with respect of your local laws. These are a fairly new concept and we don't need irresponsible jerks ruining for everyone.

Add this to your cart. You'll be happy you did.

title: he seemed to really like it. It was a last minute Christmas Gift ...
text: I purchased this for $69.95 and the next day it was listed for $49.95. Amazon corrected this right away and will be refunding me the $20 difference so I'm extremely impressed with Amazon's customer service. My husband is a lefty so it was a little hard for him to control at first but once he got the hang of it, he seemed to really like it. It was a last minute Christmas Gift and I didn't want anything too expensive and this fit the bill perfectly. IT DOES NOT NEED TO BE REGISTERED which I find important. title: Couldn't be happier; great for messing with the dog or just ...
text:
Picked this up as my very first RC/drone based on the reviews. Couldn't be happier; great for messing with the dog or just messing around on the weekends. Instructions aren't in precise English, but you can definitely put 2 and 2 together to master the controls. A bit on the louder side for indoor use, but the price/value is a steal. Great for use outside, with the lights, camera mode, and high speed mode. Battery life is rather short at 5-7 mins, but I didn't realize that's really for EVERY drone out there, even the $400 ones.

This model seems to be one of the more popular models so there are a bunch of accessories you can get. The battery it comes with is 500 mah, and I picked up a 4x set of 680 mah for extra flight time and swapping for a solid 30 mins or so of play time. Supposedly that's the way a lot of hobbyists do it. I HIGHLY recommend getting extra batteries regardless of what drone you get. I also picked up some custom propellers and propeller guards for some customization, which were a screw in away. Totally worth it.

East to fly, control, and master. Would absolutely recommend as a gift for a young kid or first time drone flyer.

My brother in-law had to swim with his snorkel in the lake to get the drone, and the thing still worked. I was pleased for the money I paid. Plus, it takes good video and pictures.

text: I love this thing! I have been slowly modifying it, but it is great. The cheap card reader it comes with is really temperamental, so do yourself a favor and order a real card reader and about 6 more batteries, because you are always going to want to fly it!

title: The actual copter flies great in almost any condition
text: The actual copter flies great in almost any condition, it can take crashes of all kinds, parts are cheap, it doesn't take much to learn how to fly it, I would actually buy it again if I ever lost mine. The only reason I hold a star is for the camera, to me is very useless, unless you are ok with really bad quality and no detail photos and videos. If you're looking for a good camera drone, this is not the one.

title: Too good to be true price and fully featured!
text: I have always wanted a helicopter ever since I was very small child . Now that drones are here this was a great opportunity to get one. The x5c is well priced and fully functional and uses radio controll instead of Bluetooth or wifi so it gets great range and stay under your controll. I would be careful as it can easily be controlled far away and high up. It is also very light and can be pushed out of sight by wind. It is strong enough to fly outside and in wind. It's trim adjustment is good and it's controller works well.  Make sure you buy extra batteries with extended capacity and a multi battery charger if you pls on extended use. The battery last about 10/12 minutes.

title: Five Stars

text: Incredible value for the price.  Solid and forgiving build.  Excellent flight characteristics and easy to fly.  Camera is basic but effective. This should sell for twice the price.

title: Very easy to fly
text: I sold it, but it's well worth the money.

title: Tough little drone
text:
One tough little drone. Bought it for my 13 year old nephew, within 20 minutes, he had flown it into the path of the 4 wheeler his sister was driving. She ran over it, stopped on it, then peeled out on it. Broke the propellers and did a little more cosmetic damage but after replacing the propellers, was like new again. Then he flew it into a tree, about 50' in the air. Using a ladder and several poles that we duct taped together, it took several whacks to free it, no damage at all. The little guy is so lite, it doesn't damage when it falls to the ground.

Couple of notes for you. Propellers are not all the same. There's two pairs, both pairs are different and it does matter which way they go on.

I about threw the plastic packaging out when I noticed that taped to the bottom was a spare set of propellers (I had bought him a separate spare pair). I only seen them by chance.

Definitely recommend buying the extra batteries with charger. It allows you to charge up to 6 batteries at a time. It does take a while to charge them but if you charge them fully, then replace as you're flying, you can almost fly non stop.

title: the times it would take off was fun, that's the only way to describe it..... UPDATED......
text:
Could have been 5 Stars, but one propeller started not spinning sometimes at start-up from the beginning, the times it would take off was fun, that's the only way to describe it.... fun: learning aerodynamics from a personal hands on level. I don't understand companies that keep coming down in price instead of just purchasing some higher quality equipment (motors). I don't want a cheaper quality product.

Didn't try to purposely use camera, but the random videos I did see were decent quality, but will freeze up and jump around some, if that's your whole purpose for buying it, don't bother, this is more of a stunt drone.

Propeller (motor) has totally stopped working now, why continuously put out constant failures, it will catch up with your profits, sooner or later.

If you're going to get one of these, get a handful of batteries and a charger, plus a repair kit (with motors), you will need it all sooner or later.

UPDATE: Well, they replaced the last one and sent a new one and everything is good now....... Re-Updated......Ok, I'm learning the industry a little, no problems with the seller at all, but the manufacturer needs to upgrade their motors, or create a whole new version.... the motors on this are only going to give you around 4 hours of flight time, if your lucky, replacement motors are reasonable but, as I'm getting ready to find out, constant replacement will get old.... again, is fun, but cheap.

title: Excellent for beginners
text:
New to the hobby, very easy to fly as long as you make sure it's orientated towards you as you fly.
Got it stuck in a tree for four months through all winds and rain storms. Finally got it down, dried it out and it still works like new...

title: Buy some extra batteries
text: This thing is BLAST to play with! I used this to learn how to fly a drone. the trick is to start slow and light on the controls. You will make this crash into the ceiling many times until you get a feel for the throttle. It feels like a cheap toy but it's actually durable. Mine has survived tons of crashes when flying it around the house. I have yet to break a prop. I don't use the guards because I destroyed them all from crashing so much. I measured the range outside and it cuts out around 200 ft in a residential area with lots of wifi signal. I modified the controller to add a 6db wifi antenna. It made the range go from 200 to 450 feet if you keep the antenna pointed in the right direction. This drone is too light to handle the wind. Go to a big open field if you want to fly high. if not, I guarantee you will get it stuck in a tree like me.

title: For the money, can't beat it.
text:
For the money, can't beat it.
Crashed it a few times around the house, then took it outside.
Flies like a champ.
Very responsive, easy to control.
Advice on altitude... It's fairly easy to go higher than planned. After the first couple hundred feet, it's easy to lose track that it's still climbing (until the LED's start flashing). I was able to bring it back down, but I could see this causing trouble if there was any wind pushing it.
As for range, I was able to fly it easily past 100 yds. I really don't know how far I'd still be able to control it; but, 100 yds is really far enough for something that you have to have in line of sight.
Camera is about the best you can hope for on a unit at this price. Indoor pictures are crappy/grainy, but who needs this to take pictures in the house. Outdoors pictures and video are actually pretty good. Everything in the 20ft-200yd range looked really good (again, for a camera/drone in this price range).
Battery life is about right for me. After 6-7 minutes, I'm ready to move on.
I haven't seriously crashed it yet. But, it looks like there are a lot of spare parts available. So, should be able to keep this thing flying, without too much expense, for a long time.
Again, for the price, hard to beat this.

title: Great little starter drone
text:
The Syma X5C 2.4G quadracopter comes with everything you need to get you started straight out of the box except for 4x AA batteries required for the remote.

In the box you get the quadracopter itself, 2 pairs of rotor guards, a spare set of rotors, battery for the copter, USB charger, small screwdriver, 2Gb Micro SD card and even a micro SD to USB converter.

The first thing you'll note about it is that everything is cheap. The USB charger is basically some wires connected to USB socket. The micro SD to USB converter is just a small piece of plastic etc. The camera uses about a 10 year old sensor.

The battery fits in a small slot on top of the camera. You simply pull the camera forward to get to the battery compartment. Unhook the battery which is connected to the copter via a small 2 wire connector (note, do not pull on the wires to disconnect the battery as you will end up pulling the wires out from the connector) and plug it into the USB charger and wait. It takes approximately 1 hour and 15 minutes to charge the battery and this will give you roughly 6 minutes of flight time.

The X5C is very light and unlike more expensive and heavier drones doesn't have things like a hover mode or a return to base function. One of the first things you should do is fit the rotor guards (these simply screw into slots next to the rotor mountings with the included screwdriver). You will need these as you will end up crashing this copter.

I would suggest flying the copter in a basement or similar place where there is no wind to get used to the controls. The remote is geared for when the camera is facing towards you. So left, right, rotate, forward, backwards etc. is setup to where the camera is pointing. If the camera is pointing away from you controls are effectively reversed as you look at it. One handy feature, if you can't see the camera is that the drone comes with four lights. Two orange on the front and two green on the back. The two orange lights are where the camera is and therefore makes it easy to figure out what remote inputs are required. This is especially handy once you get outdoors and the copter becomes small enough that you cannot really see the camera itself. One of the things you will want to do is practice hovering as this doesn't come with an auto hover feature. Once you have that down then take it outside. The reason I say this is that this copter is so light that it doesn't take much for the wind to effect its flight path and characteristics. Even on an apparently calm day, when the copter is 50ft to 100ft off the ground, chances are you will encounter some wind which will effect the copter so learning to control it first in a windless environment is a plus.

After attaching the battery and powering on the copter and the remote, you move the left controller all the way forward and backwards to pair the controller with the copter. When you start to rise you will notice the copter drifting, usually either left or right but sometimes also forward or backwards. Luckily on the remote are some trim buttons so that you dial the drift down a minimum. I've not been able to completely null out the trim but its fairly easy to get it to a point where its nearly stable and easy to control.

On your first few flights you will crash the X5C until you get used to the controls. The X5C is fairly flexible and will survive a good few crashes without harm. One thing to note however is that when flying and the battery runs out, you effectively lose all control of the copter so make sure when getting to that point that you are not a couple of hundred feet off the ground and far away (it has a range of roughly 300ft and will rise to approximately 200ft although I've not had it that high yet). The battery lasts roughly 5-6 minutes depending on how heavily you are controlling it so try to time it that when you get close to the 5 minute mark you are bringing the copter back down and close to yourself for recovery.

One thing you will want to invest in is extra batteries and chargers. You can pick up a charger that will charge up to 5 batteries at once and extra higher capacity batteries on Amazon Prime that fit the X5C. After all, when you wait for over an hour to charge a battery, drive someplace to fly it then only have about 5 minutes of flight time, it is not so much fun.

The camera quality is quite poor. It will record 720p video but the still shots are woefully lacking (I think they are 2MP). I would suggest recording video and if you want a still, simply select a frame from your video as the single shots come out quite fuzzy.

Overall the X5C is really just a toy but it is a very fun toy. If you are thinking about getting a more expensive drone like the DJI Phantom then this is a great place to start learning how to fly it. Even if you are not wanting a more expensive drone, this is a fun little toy.

title: Great Beginner Quadcopter - Can Be Used For FPV
text:
I'm not a quadcopter expert by any means, but I have flown a number of different models. The Syma X5C-1 is the best handling and easiest to fly of any of the entry level quadcopters I have flown. I like the UDI U818A and have three. They are fun to fly, forgiving, and have survived many crashes. However, since I bought the Symas, I now have two X5C-1s, I rarely fly the U818A. The X5C-1 is more stable, easier to hover, handles the wind better, and can survive some rough treatment. It will carry an 808 Keychain camera if you want upgraded video, but will not fly well with a Mobius or anything heaver. With a little practice, it can be flown inside or out.

It can be equipped for first person view. I recently mounted a Spektrum Ultra Micro FPV Camera & VTX (SPMVA1100) atop one of my X5C-1s and I'm getting some great FPV video through a remote monitor I mounted atop the Syma transmitter. I highly recommend the X5C-1 as a great beginner quadcopter!

title: Great starter drone and excellent value (unless it breaks)
text:
UPDATE -- I had to lower my review to 3 stars. The battery charger is poorly constructed. It broke after a week. I ordered a replacement from Amazon, which ships from Hong Kong. I've been waiting 3 weeks and still nothing.

This was a xmas present for my 6 year old son, and truth be told, his dad. I wasn't sure how much we'd like flying a drone so didn't want to start off with something expensive. I purchased this drone because it had the best combination of review scores and price on Amazon. It also seemed to be fairly popular, high volume of sales, which means replacement parts would likely be easily available. So far, we both really enjoy the drone. It didn't take long to figure out the basics, but we still need plenty of practice. Now that we have it, I wonder if the model with headless functionality would have been a better move. It can be difficult to know which direction the drone is flying, so that can make it hard to fly it in the direction you'd like to. Hard to complain given the price. The other nice thing is that Syma shares parts with the higher end model, so you can re-use parts from this model as you upgrade.

However I choose this one because of the price and the availability of replacement parts.  It is a guarantee that I would crash this so we would need to be able to fix it. title: Excellent fathers day gift! Excellent Quadcopter for the price. Easy to fly Indoors/Outdoors.
text:
I absolutely Love this Quadcopter. This would be my first to own, but not my first to fly. Im an avid RC "whatever" individual and I was quite happy with the value for the dollar on this.

So here's my details
Pros:
Easy to fly
VERY crash-damage Resistant
Lots of parts available
Camera is rather decent
Control sensitivity, trim, and modes are very good
My Flight time averages 7-10 minutes as long as Im not trying to fly extremely high or fast. A controlled indoor flight is more towards 10, Outdoor more towards 7. This is on the stock battery that came with the unit
Charge time is approx. 45 minutes to 75 minutes. I use the USB port on my Surface Tablet's brick and that does a nice job. Also my ASUS tablet wall wart USB port charger works just as well. (I believe these are both 2.1 amp)
Outdoor wind control - under 10 mph and you can "battle" it.. if you are a Newbie, Keep it low while you learn and cut altitude thrust if needed so it does not get carried away.

Cons:
would like the movement sensors to be a bit faster to respond.
the controller has a bit too much "fake" to it. The LCD is nice to see where your trim ammounts are, what mode you are in, and if you are in Low or high power mode, but the Fake plastic buttons and nav pad just make it a bummer when you get it out of the box.
The Range... SUCKS.. however the mod to use a router antenna works fantastic and takes just a few minutes to do.
The default action of the software to repeat the last command when it goes out of range also sucks. If it performed the same action as "low battery" it would be allright but if you are fighting the wind at say 75 feet up and you sideways drift say 30 feet and it goes out of range, it will just keep going..and going.. If the wind gust stops and you were at full power with a forward tilt, and a fresh battery, Forget it. its gone. I would imagine it would go for miles before you saw it again. Might be faster just to buy a new one :)
Lastly, Hovering is not an exact science. It can not anticipate thrust changes due to the height off the ground so if you are hovering in your living room and fly over your carpet and transition to flying over the couch, the amount of thrust required to maintain horizontal level flight changes so you need to react to it with slight adjustments.

A Few Nifty Things about this that I feel was missing when I bought it:
1. Explanation on the modes. The modes change what stick does the head rotation and what stick does the sideways movement (a Strafe if you will). Mode 1 which is out of the box, has the rotation on the left stick along with Up/down thrust control. The Right stick handles forward/backwards and the "strafing" left to right. Mode 2 puts the strafing on the Left stick and moves the turning of the head on the right stick. This feels more like flying a rc airplane than a copter. you can move forward and steer left and right with just one stick on mode 2. Its a personal preference thing
2. High and low power mode. Low power indoors, High power outdoors. the High power really increases the aggressiveness of the steering but did not do much for overall lift. High power saved my bacon when I was flying it outdoors and a wind gust caught it and almost took it..

Overall, Just a fun little copter to fly!

text: Great quadcopter for indoor or outdoor use! It was left outside for 2 weeks and it was filled with water when I found it and it still runs perfectly! Very durable and easy to control. title: Five Stars
text: had a blast with it

title: Exceeds all expectations.
text: This thing is an amazing value!  I have a lot fixed wing RC experience and took an interest in teaching myself how to fly and shoot video and photos with a drone.  I am used to spending hundreds on RC, but thought I'd take a shot with the X5C because I figured there would be a lot of crashing and bashing going on and I didn't want to beat up an expensive piece of technology.  So, I didn't expect much. I was wrong.  This thing flies like a champ right out of the box.  Again, I have a lot of experience with RC, so I was already familiar with trims, orientation, etc....but I never dreamed I'd be shooting video and accurate aerial photos by the 3rd flight out of the box.  Sure, it seems flimsy, but remember it is important to keep weight to a minimum.  At first blush, the transmitter looks toyish, but it functions perfectly and is great for learning controls, orientation, etc.  I recommend buying a few extra batteries with a multi-charger as well. Once you start messing with this thing you won't want to stop.  Great fun and easy to fly....exceeds expectations for the price.  Truly a great value.  Check it the video I captured and put together with about 10 minutes of work.

title: Disappointing Syma Motors and Quality Control
text:
I have been a long time fan of Syma products with around seven different helis etc. I bought this on a one-day special (arrived Dec 9th) and it was great fun, stable and easy to fly with High and Low speed options for novices. This thing can be fast and get away far enough it is hard to see which direction it is heading. So, I have spent quite a lot of time in the scrub looking for the downed quad. All but TWO times that was my fault for losing a clear sight of it.

Now to the two missing stars for this review. The first time I lost it, it headed off and would not respond to controls even though it was still well within radio range. It dipped on one corner and sadly, that dipped corner was away from me so off it went. I pulled off power but it ignored any and all control input. My guess is the flight controller software was trying to get it back up level before managing another command so the drop to ground was queqed and thus ignored. Syma has built into the flight controller for it to quickly go to ground about three seconds after it loses radio contact so that probably saved me an even longer walk when it over-rode the command queue.

On recovery, one CCW motor was running at about half-speed and that was the dropped-corner that dictated the fly-away direction at that time. I figured it would be quicker and easier to just buy some motors so got a four-pack, 2 x CW and 2 x CCW for about 9-bucks (arrived about Dec 9th) . I am a retired Engineer so being anal about things, I used a sharpie to write numbers on the top and bottom of frame halves, the propellers and also indicators inside for the orientation of all four sets of motor wires so I wouldn't get it wrong soldering the new motor back in.

It took about an hour to get it apart, install the motor and get it flying again, but it was perfect and good to have it back flying. Two days later another fly away. On retrieval the same issue, one motor barely turning. When I pulled it apart it was the other CCW motor running at about half speed. I will solder the replacement in today.

I have to say I am REALLY disappointed with Syma as I now have used the two CCW motors I bought and have no spares, so I guess I have to shell out another 9-bucks so that I have two CCW spares in case I crash it.

One motor going out is understandable, but not TWO in such a short time and NOT BOTH CCW motors. Obviously a quality control thing, I am guessing. This is annoying as I was so happy with the X5C I intended to buy an X8C, but now not so sure of Syma products.

title: Inaccurate range listing.
text: Manual is very inaccurate. Says 40 meter max range. This unit went over half a mile before it shut down. Unit was lost for 2 months and finally found, no longer works.

title: Great fun given some TLC
text:
I have a lot of fun with the quad. I think you can really get a lot out of it if you take the time to read several blogs and watch some YouTube videos.
There are many tweaks that can be done to improve the flying experience. To prevent fires, etc. I highly recommend getting a quality charger like those made by Hitec. It is just as important to know how to care and store the batteries(with a 50% charge) as it is to know how to charge them.
LiPo batteries are very sensitive to charging rates and other conditions.
Also buy quality batteries. don't cheap out on anything so critical.
As far as motors, these are cheap motors and can burn up in an instant if the props are blocked from turning freely. Make sure to go to full down throttle to cut the motors if you run into any problem like the craft is not flying properly or it brushed a tree, etc. that may have jammed a prop but it is flying too high to see what happened. If anything is not normal, cutting the throttle should be the first thing to do. Let is fall if it has to, the body can take some abuse, within reason. And assuming you are not flying over hard ground.
Don't expect too much at one time. Learn how to fly it smoothly and with fully charged batteries at the start and if you have disassembled it before make sure all the tiny screws are in place and fully tightened. This can be a little time consuming but ensuring the body is assembled properly so there are no loose parts or gaps where the parts come together is essential. This is an inexpensive model to enjoy and to learn from before investing into something more sophisticated and expensive. Learn from your mistakes on this one first. :)

If you are beginners, I strongly recommend tying a string or light wire to the bottom and the other end to something solid or a weight, like a small wrench, a stapler, etc. The little motors will not have enough power to overcome the additional weight. Now you can practice what all the controls do without worrying about it going out of control, hitting walls, etc. etc.

title: Bought this for Christmas for my brother. He likes ...
text: Bought this for Christmas for my brother.  He likes it a lot.  We also purchased him the case it goes in.  Nice

title: Fun toy!
text:
I had bought a "nano" drone to try my hand at flying. After playing with the "nano" I quickly came to the realization that I was REALLY bad at it. Then I belatedly read some reviews that said to try one of the more sophisticated ones, and the Syma X5C was mentioned. They were right; I found this much easier to fly than the "nano". I also bought some spare blades, since every (frequent) "nano" crash had me scouring the vicinity for blades. However, this Syma has MUCH better prop protection. So it is easier to fly and survives crashes better than the little ones.
I haven't gotten proficient enough to try using the video yet, but it looks like an interesting prospect when (if) I've gotten a bit more proficient.

title: My 9 & 10 year old boys love flying this outside and they are able to control it.
text:
My 9 & 10 year old boys love flying this outside and they are able to control it. It is quite powerful and the first time we jammed the throttle up it flew up and over the house, but I was able to perform a slow decent and land without incident. the people who complain about loosing it is because the 1st time you fly this, the power will take you by surprise. I have my boys practice flying it with the rule "don't fly higher than my head" to focus on control.

Pros:
- Easy to control
- Powerful enough for outdoor use
- Lots of replacement parts are available (important as it will surely break some rotors although I have not yet)
- Cost: about $50 for a great starter drone

Cons:
- Low quality camera (should not be surprised here)
- Short flight times (about 10 minutes a charge but not a surprise)

If you are thinking of getting a drone, this is a great product to start out with.

title: awesome buy

title: High Quality Drone WELL WORTH THE MONEY
text:
I have ordered 4 drones through Amazon.com and this is the FIRST one that has worked past the 3rd flight. It's battery power is better than others selling the same drone with a different "label" but I HIGHLY recommend getting this SYMA one and not the "rebranded" one being sold by others. You can tell just by looking at the soldering on the two copters - one is BLOBS of silver and the SYMA one is neatly done with coverings - it's the details that matter!

Flight time is longer (~8-9min per battery) - it has no problem doing multiple batteries before maybe a 10 minute break to let the board cool down. Good in mild wind, HIGHLY recommend the camera mod on youtube to level out the view angle but it's great!

I have crashed this (accidentally) from ~200+ ft up straight into pavement and no problems.

If I were to buy another one for my son - this would be it but this one is MINE...ALL MINE!

title: This is my second drone and it's awesome, definitely a great drone for beginners
text: This is my second drone and it's awesome, definitely a great drone for beginners. It is easy to control and extremely durable (I've rammed it into many walls and it's dropped to the floor from 15 ft up many many times). I recommend this drone if you're looking to buy your first drone.

title: Click the button, it's worth every penny.
text:
Bought this for my son....then I stole this from my son. He has plenty of toys, don't feel bad for him. I now have a new hobby, can't put it down.

1. Flies for about 7-8 minutes.
2. Camera quality isn't great, but does the job at this price point.
3. I fly much like Charlie Brown flies a kite, I don't miss a tree.
4. Apparently indestructible. Shook this out of a 60 foot tree and didn't damage it at all.
5. Solid against winds less than 15mph.
6. Replacement parts (just in case) are stupid cheap. Spent $7 and I have enough parts for a complete rebuild (if it ever breaks).
7. I'm buying another one because my son is jealous.

Update:
I'm glad I bought the spare parts when I did, I've lost two motors so far. Replacing them is just a touch of solder, but concerning since it's less than two months old. I'm looking into the FPV kits for this now. It will be a nice practice unit until I step up with a more advanced quad-copter. Also, I'm replacing the 2.4gh antenna with something adequate, the range is pretty limited once you get used to flying around.

I still love this thing.

title: Syma X5c Quadcopter exceed my expectations for 30 bucks
text:
Ordered the Syma X5c Quadcopter from Tenergy(seller).

The drone has everything that I need except for one(more on this later)

Pros:
1. price - 30 bucks is inexpensive for you to learn how to fly
2. Decent camera - takes photos and videos
3. Decent batter life - gives you about 8+ minutes of flying time
4. Crash but doesn't burn - have crashed it multiple times and it still holds well.

Cons:

1. Doesn't handle wind but that's not negative since this is light weight

There is some learning curve needed to take photos and videos.
What I would like is a FPV(First Person Viewing) camera so I can watch the video on my camera but am told you can remove the existing
camera and replace with an FPV camera.
Ordered extra batteries and am off to flying this.

Ignore the reviewers that say get an expensive one(like 200-300 bucks) - for what? This is good for beginners and occasional use.

title: Learn to fly for inexpensive
text:
First time UAS/drone buyer and user here. So I've logged maybe 3 hours total on this my first drone. I wanted to start out inexpensive. First extra batteries are a must. Second.....this is a toy any expectation otherwise is silly.

Pro's ....inexpensive; can be crashed and dropped from very high (50' into concrete) and still survive; somewhat "fun" to fly

Con's.... range 180' line of site then you have intermittent connection which can cause erratic flight and result in a crash; I'd say to really start flying there is a decent learning curve but I wanted to "learn" how to fly and you can with this drone...just know its going to take patience and crashes; it's insanely difficult to fly in any wind...ANY. if you take it above tree line be prepared for lots of patience to try and land it; Battery life maybe 6-7 max but if its aloft in wind and the battery dies you will loose connection and crash....

Photos themselves are worthless, but video is fine (as long as you are not thinking you are getting hi-quality or detailed footage).  I purchased multiple different batteries with this drone as well, and be aware that about 1 in 5 are worthless.  You can expect 5-7 minutes (with camera running, and there is not wind) per battery.

There is no "return home" function like 400% more expensive models.  It's awesome for a beginner before commitment to a larger model.  I haven't tried the camera yet.  Also, get more batteries as flight time is 6-7 minutes with a 1 hour charge time. I got a six pack.

title: So much fun to fly!!!

title: One motor had problems right out of the box.
text:
So I bought this drone to use with my cleaning business to take before and after videos. Unboxing was a typical experience, with minimal parts. I assembled the blade guards, hooked up the battery and voila she’s ready to fly.

Except the remote needed 4 AA batteries that were not included. This is important if you want to give this as gift and want them to use it right away.

Now, the battery came with enough charge for one full session of flying. The instruction manual says you should charge the battery for 75 minutes for a whole 7 minutes of flying time. Ouch. That’s kinda crummy.

On first flight the drone takes off... and immediately starts going side ways by itself. Whiskey tango foxtrot. I play around with the adjustments on the remote but I’m getting no where. After about 10 minutes of launching, crashing, flipping and cussing at the drone the battery is drained and needs another recharge.

This gives me time to inspect the drone and see if there any mechanical issue with it. I spin each blade and find that one of them isn’t spinning freely. At the full rotation it stops, or catches, and requires a little force to move again. I found the culprit. I added a drop of oil to the assembly in hopes that it would fix the issue but it didn’t.

Undeterred I stuck it out and tried to fly the drone again and adjust the controls as much as possible.

With a sticking motor this drone just isn’t predictable. Vertical height is affected due to the motor playing catch up, horizontal travel is constant, and forget about maintaining height.

Overall, the construction of the unit is good for the price, the flying experience (although affected by the faulty motor) was great, and if the motor weren’t damaged I would have kept the drone. It’s in a box waiting for a return to amazon. 3 stars.

title: Awesome drone for the $
text: This is my first drone and I love it.  For the price you can't beat it, very easy to control and it will fly VERY high.  Much higher than the stated 50 meters.  Just try not to get over confident when learning I got mine stuck in a tree.  Would definitely recommend this to anyone.

title: A great budget drone
text:
A great entry-level quadcopter! I researched a bunch of different ones and saw a lot of people recommending this one. I've been very satisfied with it and the camera quality is amazing for the price.

The instruction book leaves a lot to be desired, but that's okay because you'll get the hang of it pretty fast. When you're starting out, be sure to use it in a wide open area so that it doesn't fall into somebody's yard.

Also, because each battery gives you less than 10 minutes of flight time, you'll want to get some extra batteries and a multi-battery charger. I'm using Keenstone batteries and a Quadpro charger and I've been happy with them both.

title: Great for amateur enthusiasts
text:
We're not hard core RC connoisseurs, and we haven't tried the camera yet, but this is a really fun gadget to have. The controls are pretty easy to grasp and the flips are pretty cool.

It is very lightweight, so wind has a big effect on it, but ours has taken a few pretty spectacular spills and is holding up well.

It would be nice if it had a greater tendency to land upright and it's a little hard to tell what direction it's facing in daylight. The lights are great at night.

Remember to register your drone with the FAA!

title: Such a small price to pay for pure enjoyment of flying
text: Such a small price to pay for pure enjoyment of flying. Camera works good too. A word to the wise.......add something to the body to be able tell which direction the unit is facing, otherwise you will have no idea of what your taking a picture of.

title: Excellent value for the price
text:
Excellent value for the price! Lost one in a very tall tree when we inexplicably lost control of it on a windy day (so beware folks, try not to fly it too close to things it can get stuck in that you can't reach). Bought another one because we loved it so much. It's hard to imagine how a drone that's so inexpensive also does video and pretty decent video at that. We ended up using a black permanent marker to cover one side of the drone so we could tell which side was the front and which was the back.

It comes with:
> extra blades (since those are the most likely to break),
> guards for when you are first learning to fly it,
> a sim card and sim card reader, a battery for the drone itself,
> a flimsy charger (which works just fine - lights up red when it's charging and turns off when not),
> a giant ass remote control which requires 4 AA batteries,
> and a screwdriver to open the battery compartment (that's a nice touch).

I would recommend getting extra batteries for the drone. The charge only lasts about 6 minutes or so and if you want to keep playing with it, it's just easier to switch the batteries than wait 20-30 minutes for the battery to charge. This is the one we got but seems to be currently unavailable: [[ASIN:B00Q8GQJK0 Teenitor®2pcs Genuine Syma X5C X5 3.7V 500mAh 20C Lipo Battery(X5C-11)]]

We've had the drone for about 6 months (including the one we lost) and it's pretty fun to play with. I don't know exactly what the range is but we have a bilevel house and it could go way higher than our rooftop (which we anxiously watched in case it got stuck!) and across our entire yard. Beware that it is VERY light so on windy days you can easily lose control of the drone.

title: Great starter hexicopter.
text: Works great. Make sure to follow directions to pair quad with controller. Flies great and very easy to learn how to fly. Make sure you fly this in open field the first time. It seems solid and took several drops onto tall grass from 20+ feet in the air with no visible I'll effects. Looking forward to taking it out again. Didn't test the camera because of darkness approaching. Lights make this drone very easy to see in the twilight.

title: Christmas

title: Durable and fun

title: Five Stars
text: great gift and built well..8 year old loves it and can control very easy

title: Great Quad Copter for the Money
text: My wife gave me this quad for Christmas.  Controlling the quad takes some practice but after half a dozen flights I've become pretty good at it.  The thing to remember is take it slow, and fly it in an open area the first few times so you can get the hang of it.  Flight duration is between 6 and 8 minutes depending on the camera operation so extra batteries are a plus.  Video quality from the camera is ok, it's a 2 MP so don't expect hi-def video.  I think a lot of the negative reviews are caused by people who have unrealistic expectations of what a $50 quad can do.  There's no flight automation, it doesn't come home when it looses connection with the controller, nor is it position stabilized so it tends to drift around. Also, when the battery gets low, the running lights flash a few times and then the motors shut off.  That can be a problem if it's a 150 feet up over trees.  Because it's so light, when the motors shut off it just sort of falls slowly to the ground, not a big deal unless it's over trees or water.  Also, because it's light, and not particularity powerful.  It's fairly susceptible to wind, if the winds are over 8-10 MPH it can be blown away.  I don't consider this thing an "inside" toy.  It's got four blades spinning hella fast and can break things it hits.  Keep your fingers AWAY from the blades, they aren't sharp but as fast as they spin, they don't need to be to open you up.  Get it outside in an open area, get it 20 or 30 feet up and have fun!  It's light, and pretty durable most of my landings have been semi controlled crashes and the quad is none the worse for it.  Overall, I think it's a great deal for a starter quad copter.

title: Five Stars
text: OK

title: Kids loved their Christmas gift
text: Kids loved their Christmas gift. Even though it is rated for 14+ years, my 9 year old granddaughter was flying it like a pro within an hour. Batteries were supposed to last for about 5 minutes of flying time but it turned out to be more like 8-10 minutes.

title: Great Product for the context of the price
text:
First of all, please remember this is a $50 Drone, don't go expecting a world class product like a Phantom or Parrot drone, its a $50 drone made in China, but with all that in mind this is great product, lots of fun, and better quality than I expected.

Here are my pros and cons

Pros:
Cheap
So much fun
Easy to set up
Video Quality is better than I expected
takes a tumble well, crashed countless times, still good as new

Cons:
Battery lasts about 6mins and takes 90mins to recharge
Instruction manual is poor, google translated from Chinese probably
Its almost too light, it gets thrown around by the wind a lot which makes it hard to control in wind
the white colour makes it hard to see against the sky

Advice:
Buy extra batteries, they aren't expensive.
buy the coloured blades upgrade, they'll make it easier to see against the sky
get a Sharpie and write your address and phone number on it in case you lose it.
read the instructions carefully, look at youtube clips of this drone, you'll learn more about it.
the camera on off isn't the button on the top right corner as with previous models, its the switch near the left control stick, I nearly returned mine.
Put a mark on the under side at the front of the drone so you can see clearly from underneath which is the front of drone, it'll help you steer.
Make sure your first flight is out side, you'll smash it against the ceiling first attempt I guarantee.
Take your time learning the controls, take it really really slow.

title: It's very basic in design but it feels like a very well built toy with features that didn't ...
text: I think this thing works exceptionally well for the price. It's very basic in design but it feels like a very well built toy with features that didn't need to be integrated to get the same price BONUS.

title: Drowning Drone
text:
I was so excited to finally play with my own quad-copter. After watching them online for many months I came across this one at a fantastic deal! I quickly ordered it and it arrived very quickly. The Amazon box was in good condition, but the box the Syma came in was already opened, the drone already assembled with loose parts in the box, and it was dirty!

I quickly forgave that if the drone were to work, however after charging it and playing around inside I couldn't get it to fly straight up. I recharged it and took it out again the next morning after reading directions even more carefully to make fine corrections. The corrections do NOT work and the drone immediately took off in any given direction based on which way I started it. Left, right, forward, and reverse corrections did absolutely nothing. To make it even worse, the drone was already halfway into the neighbors yard before I even started with the corrections. I tried every single possible orientation vs correction factor and came out at a loss. This quad-copter definitely moves, and the camera worked fine, I think. Mine came with a 4GB microSD card. I even bought a 32GB card, spare batteries and a charger. What a waste of money that was. From reviews, I most likely got a dud or a fake. The directions are even in very incorrect English with poor grammar!
I've attached a single portion of one page to show you this. The whole manual is like this.

Maybe your luck will be better than mine, maybe not. If you want to take that chance I wish you luck!

title: Birds eye view of the world.
text: Hours of fun for the whole family. See your world In another light. Easy to operate.

title: Was a gift
text: Was a gift for 12 year old boy

title: No reason not to get this
text: This is my first flying anything and I will say that it's easier than I thought. I can get a little excited and end up shooting off the wrong way but it's durable so if all else fails I just cut the throttle and let it crash. No problem with it holding up. It's so light that it falls softly even from 50ft. I'm not a young man so my reflexes are not that of my 20 year old son who has no problems flying it at all. With the mic on the camera you can hear it quit when it gets too high out of range but as it falls back into range it picks right back up. I'm amazed with the camera. How HD has become so dirt cheap so fast is incredible I think. Don't hesitate to get this for this price. Pick up some extra batteries and have some fun.

title: Perfect for beginners!
text: I have had this quadcopter for a week now and have flown it daily. It's very fun. Longer flight time would be desirable but performance is very satisfactory. Would highly recommend for first time users.

title: Awesome, but not HD.
text: A great first drone! However, don't be fooled by the "HD" camera. As you can see from pictures it is not HD and is also mounted crooked (see how most pics/video aren't level? - I rotated my pic to make it level) Other than that it's super fun! Buy some extra batteries and be wary of wind! It's light so it will fly away quickly!

title: Five Stars
text: Great learing quadcopter, and a very good price, too.

title: What do ya expect at this price point?
text: Just can't get this guy aligned... fun trying to fly it, but it just seems to have bias I can't correct. Of course, it could just be my lack of skills. ;)

title: Unbelievable Drone for the Price
text: I can't believe this quadcopter is not more expensive. Started flying it right out of the box and got pretty proficient at it after a few minutes. The camera works well for both photos and videos. You will need to take a few until you get used to the angle of the camera. 360 function works great and makes you feel like a pro. I do wish the batteries lasted longer but 7-10 mins actually feels like a long time. It is surprisingly resilient as well...ran it into a tree on my first flight at full speed and it still flew right as rain after dusting it off. Definitely a beginner drone but I expect to upstate to a more versatile one later.

title: Best quad copter for under $50!
text: Wow, this is honestly the best quadcopter for under $50! I've had multiple Hubsan drones or quadcopters and they break way to easily! This is the best drone for beginners, as it can record video, do flips, and has a pretty decent controller and range. The Battery time is pretty good: 7 minutes with prop guards and around 10-11 without. The charge time is about an hour with an iPhone/Usb wall adapter since wall chargers are 500mah out (every our) and the battery is 500mah. If you are not sure when charging is done, a helpful LED indicator on the charger will turn off. The quadcopter seems big but is really light as it weighs under 2 pounds, and because of that, high falls don't damage the quadcopter. I've had mine fall out of the air from a very high up altitude and no visible damage, so I pushed throttle and started flying again! So, all in all, this is the best quadcopter for under $50 or even $100 for beginners! Ariel images shown below

title: Neat little drone.
text:
I am new to the world of RC drones. I read and did my homework on them and a lot of stuff I read and saw in reviews said for the newbie who is (as Pink Floyd says in a song) Learning To Fly, this was the best drone to learn with due to its cost and durability. My brother got an X5C for Christmas and he brought his in so I could see it in person. He did an indoor demo flight so I could see it in action and I was impressed. I decided to buy one of my own.

When it arrived I hadn't read the sellers description closely where it stated "note: does not include a micro sad card" and was not pleased. I had even reboxed it and started a return then saw those cards are very inexpensive and I wasn't really buying this for the cam. This is to play with and learn to pilot so I can eventually move up to a good FPV equipped drone. I decided I'd go ahead and keep it because I can always get that card anytime. Amazon was very helpful when I called to cancel the return.

Once I unboxrd it and read through the poorly written broken English instruction manual it was time to charge the batteries and get this bird in flight. Binding the copter with the controller is easy. Power on the controller, set the copter on a level surface and turn on the power on the copter and when the lights go from a rapid pulse to a slower blink move the left stick up til you hear a beep then all the way down. The controller beeps again and the lights on the copter burn steady. The copter will now respond to the controller commands. I've flown.....and wrecked a few of those 20 dollar Costco sphere type copters which really were hard to control for a newbie. Those spheres use an infrared type control so you need to keep the controller pointed at the aircraft at all times or it loses control and goes amuck and 9 times out of ten results in its demise. The controls for this drone have a totally different feel. You have a lot more precise control over the aircraft since I was indoors I was trying out hovering and simple movements. My suggestion for the beginner is find a large indoor area to get used to the drone's movements and controls.

All in all I like this drone. If you are looking for a good quality and durable drone this is perfect learning quad for the cost. I took off a star for the ad card not being included but that's nothing big. I'm happy with it. Can't wait to try outdoor flying.

title: Great drone for the price.
text:
So this thing is sort of cheaply made. The instruction manual is in broken english and the controller and buttons all feel really cheap. Sort of like what you would find on a dollar store rc. The drone itself also seems pretty flimsy, but I'm sure that was more to keep the weight down.

All that said, it's pretty easy to fly, has a camera, runs for about 10 minutes on a charge and does all that for about thirty bucks. You really can't beat the price on this drone. Wouldn't hesitate to recommend this to anyone looking for a drone and not wanting to spend a fortune. Not sure how long it'll hold up, but again it's so cheap I could just buy a new one.

title: Nice quadcopter for beginners
text: Given the cost, I was surprisingly impressed at the quality of the quadcopter. The battery life holds up decently well under fall/summer temperatures, decreases when exposed to winter weather. That is expected given the batteries are Li-ion based, but I think is something that should be taken in consideration when using the quadcopter. Nice speed, holds up well to slight crash landings which speaks well to the mechanical strength of the plastic frame and blades.

title: Great beginner quad
text:
Great beginner quad. I took off the camera for weight and it is very responsive. I can fly in a 10mph cross wind without issue.

I ordered another quad and this one is so much more responsive. For a low priced quad this beats out the others. I replaced the rear props and guards with blue ones to help identify orientation.

title: Awesome Toy and Picture Taker
text:
This is the best starting out Quadcopter. What you get for the money is amazing. This is my 2nd one in less than a month. It was very easy to learn how to fly. I did practice touch and go's in my living room. Learning how to control it etc... I took it outside and flew it very carefully for several days in a row. It took great photos and video. I had no complaints. It has 2 red lights in the front and 2 green in the back. You have to make sure that you know which direction the drone is pointed and keep it in that direction or your controls end up backwards. Flying it in the daytime was very easy. I wanted to see those lights at night ad decided to try it at night. I somehow got it turned around and it took off in the wind after I achieved an altitude of at least 200-300 feet. I lost it in a pasture heavily dense with trees and rattle snakes. I looked but could not find it.
Since then I bought one of those key finders that I attached to the bottom and you can find it with a beep of about 80 feet or so. The 2nd one handles exactly as the 1st one. Super fast and fun to fly. If you have never had a drone before this is the one to get. You won't be disappointed. I won't fly it at night.

title: Treed, rain, wind, works!?!?!!
text: So I've had this drone for years now and finally got it stuck in a tree 😌.  It was up there about 2 weeks.  It went through high winds, and rain.  Then it fell low enough to recover it.  I charged the battery and work like in was never stuck!

title: Most fun toy ever
text:
This thing is a lot of fun to learn and fly. Its enough of a challenge to be interesting, yet easy enough to fly to be fun.
Having spare batteries makes the learning process go quicker because you don't have to wait 2 hours for the original battery to recharge before flying again. I get 5 to 7 minutes with the original 500 mAh battery and 8 to 9 minutes from the spare 600 mAh batteries. The batteries recharge in 90 to 120 minutes. A faster charger might reduce recharging times.

When I got the quad I took off the camera because I've seen youtube videos and the recording showed mostly the ground and hardly any of the horizon. There's a way to point the camera more horizontally and I'll eventually do that with mine.

The quad flies nice and stable, is easy to trim if there's no breeze and takes crashes and keeps ticking.
It has 2 sensitivity levels. Some might call one beginner level and the other expert level. The button for changing the setting is the silver one at the upper left of the radio. The operator is notified that the change took place by a quiet little beep. I can hear it OK because i have good hearing.
As a beginner its hard to fly in a wind of 10+ MPH. The best I can do is to fly straight into a strong wind and then let the breeze blow the quad back toward me. That might not sound like much fun, but its a good way to get accuston to the radio controils. Setting the skill level button so the quad goes to the expert position allows much better flying when the wind blows.

After flying a few weeks I'm gaining the ability to keep orientation better and its getting to the point its almost second nature to steer the quad. I've even enjoyed flying at night a few times. Whether doing flights at night or in full daylight its a lot better at first to keep the quad as close as possible. Its really easy to quickly let the wind get the quad too far away when the wind is 10+ mph.

I've found that rather than trying to regain control after losing my orientation its working a lot better to cut power and let the quad hit the ground. The quad will be taken really high really quickly in a strong wind when the quad is set to beginner mode, but changing to expert level can help overcome the wind and help keep the quad from being taken really high too quickly. The thing is light and really durable, so its better to crash it to the ground than to lose control and hang up in a tree. There's times I didn't do that and the wind carried it into the trees where it hung up for anywhere from several hours to 2 to 3 days before I could get it down. Its so light weight that the wind can carry it away very quickly. But at the same time its light weight makes it real easy to fly when there's little breeze.

I learned the basics of the controls with the prop guards installed, but believing the prop guards are partly responsible for making the quad a lot harder to recover from trees I removed the prop guards.

The digital readout on the radio works, but its more of a distraction than useful and is better left unwatched. The radio batteries outlast the quad batteries by at least 10 times.

I've let it get out of range a few times because of the wind. When out of range it takes the quad 3 or 4 seconds to cut power, so when you think you're going too far and you're not in complete control cut power to prevent losing the quad. Range is a few hundred feet. By my reckoning that's plenty far enough because as it gets further away it gets too small to see.

I like to fly in a 40 acre field because I can stand in the middle and have room to fly, to try to regain control if I lose it and to let the quad drop to the ground before it gets into trees.

One thing I was a bit slow to learn is that when I put in a fresh battery and fly again immediately its easy to forget that the quad will have a LOT more power and respond faster. That means it will get too high too quick in the wind.

Important parts are available to order and they seem to be priced reasonably. I wish the reciever and other electronics were available so I could experiment putting something together with a scratch built frame.

Would I buy this again. Oh yes.
Would I recommend this quad to a friend whose interested in getting started in RC toys. Oh yes.

title: Syma X5C Still Works!
text: We had one Syma X5C that was fine and worked well. Kids and neighbors loved it. Dad flew the Syma X5C over a corn field...first mistake. It traveled too far...second mistake. Landed in an unharvested corn field and could not be found...third mistake. Two more Syma X5C drones were ordered the same day that the one was lost. However, after the corn was harvested a few days later, the kids found the lost Syma X5C. It had been run over by a corn picker and was outdoors for a couple days. Had a couple bent rotors, but still works!

title: Great entry level quad coptor
text: Great entry level quad coptor. Easy to learn to fly, decent video. This coptor is very tough!!! I crashed mine from over 300 feet with no damage! It was my mistake when I flew it too high in high winds. I tracked the path and found it in someone's front yard several blocks away. The video is very funny. I picked it up, reconnected the transmitter and it flew! I have spare parts for it but never have used them! I suggest this as a starter to learn to fly!!!

title: My son still plays with it nearly a year later
text:
This unit is fun to play with and fairly durable. The buttons on the remote are not labeled, so learning it is through trial and error. We didn't even know it did flips until my son hit the right button. The camera records if you have a micro-SD card in it and hit the right button, but without seeing what you're recording as you're flying, you aren't likely to be producing masterpieces.
You'll definitely want to get more batteries and another charger. The flight time for each battery is only about 10 minutes.
But this thing is still working nearly a year later. And my son still takes it outside to fly it. It was a good purchase for the price.

title: Awesome once you take the time to learn the controls  :)
text: I bought two of these for my remote control junkie boyfriend for Christmas. He's really into rock crawlers and expensive professional remote control big-boy toys that cost hundreds of dollars. I did a ton of research but still worried that these would feel like a cheap toy to him. Much to my satisfaction, he absolutely loves flying them. We fly together in the backyard and have become experts at Quad recovery using only a spool of fishing line and a lead weight. It took me exactly 27 seconds to get it stuck in a tree the first time I flew it. After that, I let him show me how to use the controls.  ;)  We take tons of pics and videos and while the quality is abysmal, we still get excited every time to see what we were able to capture. I take a lot of pictures of my quad stuck in trees. He takes a lot of the roof of the house. Which reminds me, I really need to buy some moss remover.

title: Excellent Then I took it outside
text:
If I ever get it back my review may change.
The thing has a mind of it's own.
I went through the trouble of calibrating the thing indoors because it wanted to race hard left on initial start up. I was able to get it to trim the controls to where it hovered perfectly still for me. Excellent
Then I took it outside.
Winds were less than 5mph but the copter started to drift backwards and up as if caught in a breeze and it refused to respond to the forward or decend command, until it drifted far enough out of range that it dropped into a tree on the edge of the field.
Maiden flight less than 15 seconds.
Now I'm waiting for the Autum leaves to drop just to see if I can find it and if it's salvageable.
