title: Worth the money! Great fun!
text: Great product for a great price! It even got caught in a tree for 3 days (operator error) and came down (50 ft) and still worked beautifully. Great for Jr, High High school kids! Nice first Drone! The battery could last a tad longer, otherwise I would have given it a 5 star.

title: Good beginner quad.
text:
This was my first quad and unfortunately it had a short life. About a week after getting it, I was flying where I always flew and the wind drug the drone out further than I could see, I thought it was past the trees/brush and closer to the road but it disappeared into the brush and was never found again. BEFORE I lost it I definitely had fun. It's a great first drone; however, if you're serious about learning, you may want to consider the Ares Ethos QX130. I purchased that after the Syma X5SW I purchased to replace this had a motor go bad after less than a week of use.

The Ares is much easier to control and more predictable. I had it in a similar spot to when I lost the X5C and it was easier to recover.

Overall, for the price, this is a great quad to learn on.

title: Great quality for the money.
text: The copter control and stability are good and I've taken some pictures and video that is very good for this caliber of toy. I modified the battery compartment by snipping off the lower battery support; that makes it a lot easier to place and connect the battery. I can also fit a larger battery capacity for longer flight time. It does tend to climb away from me requiring that I almost stop the rotors to loose some altitude. This copter is incredibly lightweight, but handles a breeze just fine. I can land it precisely on a 2' circle. Fun to play with. I haven't tested the radio range yet.

title: Two Stars
text: This product worked about 3hours then 2 of the motors burned out.  One wont even turn junk!!!

title: Be careful...
text: Great toy but lost it the 1st time they took it out. When it flies out of range there is no way to locate it. We searched for hours. The extended warranty is worth nothing if you don't have the broken toy to send back. Lost $45 and had some very unhappy kids.

title: Aprendi a volarlo
text: Me divertí

title: I came to realize that battery life was not very good, and averaged about 7 minutes of air time
text:
Out of the box, it seemed to have the expected quality for a $50 quadcopter (not very well built, but solid). I took a lot of time to familiarize myself with controls. During this time, I came to realize that battery life was not very good, and averaged about 7 minutes of air time. I did not take any photos as I was just practicing to be able to use it on a "longer" flight.

When I finally flew it on that "long" flight, it went up about 50-75ft and seemed to have lost contact with the controller. It was carried away by the wind and lost in my neighborhood. Overall, I was very surprised that at a distance of under 100 ft, and after only a few hours of total use (less than 5), it was gone.

Pros: It seemed relatively durable. It took a lot of falls as I practiced and keep operating normally. It is inexpensive and has a camera.
Cons: Camera/battery compartment tends to open during use and it lost contact with included controller from under 100ft away, resulting in total loss.

title: Fragile, broke on first flight. / Easy Fix - now awesome!
text:
It literally lasted 30 seconds before it broke! We received it, charged it up and headed outside to fly it. We fitted the optional bumpers and enabled the video recording. It was flown over a grassy area (so would have had a soft landing) - it flew around 6 feet up in the air and then came slowly to the ground (not a crash but what I would only describe as a 'hard landing'). Since then one of the motors/blades isn't firing up and to add insult to injury one of the LED covers came off. Very disappointing. I've had Cheerson CX-10s before and they are definitely more durable than this. Now I'm left with a broken quadcopter AND upset children. I'd return it to Amazon but since the kids really really want it up-and-working I'm having to order replacement motors and a soldering kit to get it back up and working again. I can't recommend this drone, even for the price it's simply too fragile.

- Update, for just $8 (here on Amazon) you can buy a four pack of motors - it's an easy fix (no soldering required, but you do have to snip and tie together a couple of cables. Now it's awesome and I thoroughly recommend it.

text: It's a good drone for the price. But if there is any wind at all, it will be hard to control. This thing is so lightweight it feels like you're barely holding anything in your hand.

title: Finally a low price drone that works!!
text:
I've purchased many drones both from the high end (Parrot AR) to the cheapest ones and everything in between and this one is definitely one of my favorites. Since I have a lot of experience with the quad-copters I was able to fly it right out of the box with no problem at all. It is very stable and zippy which gives you a great feeling of full control with the remote it comes with. Even after a few minutes my little brother was able to fly it without crashing. Overall for the price you get a drone that handles very smooth and hovers better than others in its price range (after calibrating it of course).
Pros:
Smoothest drone for the price
Really is the best for beginners yet still great for experienced users.
Fly's indoor and out
Light weight
Includes camera
Has a decent flying range from remote control
Cons:
Camera not extremely high resolution (but still takes good pics)
Takes an hour to charge battery but only fly's for 15 minutes (like most drones though)
Instructions it comes with are not very clear (They're chinese-translated, but many good video in YouTube)

Great drone, does everything it advertises, lots of fun to fly around, highly recommended for your own collection or as a gift.

title: Nice Quad, durable and fun.  Reviewed against the Hubsan x4 h107c
text:
I bought this drone and the hubsan x4 h107c at the same time, one for my sister and one for me. They both seem like great drones although the hubsan was a clear winner for me. The x5 is impressive because of it's size, but it is not nearly as quick and agile as the x4. The x4 can also be flown indoors, where as the x5 is too large to really enjoy it inside.

We had one major problem with this Syma x5 though, someone else near by was using a smaller syma x11 at the time, the x5 picked up the signal from that remote accidentally and took off uncontrollably. After ascending to around 200ft, and flying off to by another 500+ feet, the LEDs went out so we lost sight of it and it fell to the ground about a quarter mile from it's original position. The one good thing about that, is that I can say it's durable, it fell from it's maximum height onto an asphalt road undamaged.

title: Fun but not super easy
text: It's ok. This is my first drone and while the concept of flying it is clear, the actual process is a little more difficult. There was a slight breeze which easily pushed my drone away. This doesn't handle wind very well but given how light it is, that makes sense. I wasn't able to fly it well because of the wind, it did respond to the controls very well. The challenge is once it turns around like a 90 or 180, it's hard to figure out what way to steer. On a  flat calm non-wind day, it'd be perfect. I wasn't able to get the camera to work yet but I've only flown it once. The propellers are not overly dangerous which is good. You don't need to worry about cutting your fingers off but you shouldn't stick them near the blades anyway. It might deserve 5 stars but I was expecting to have more control than I did.

title: I works really good. Takes a moment to learn the flight controls ...
text: I actually did not expect much from this considering the price and I was very pleasantly surprised.  I works really good.  Takes a moment to learn the flight controls and adjust it, but I was flying it around my garage and house, missing lamps and obstacles in no time.  Battery works as they describe and the camera is functional.  Its a lot of fun for the money.

title: My favorite platform to play on and a great choice for beginners
text:
The X5C was my first entry into quadcopters. So many reviews existed comparing this cheap toy with much more expensive models so I decided to give it a shot. This thing is a blast and it's extremely durable. I ordered two as one was a gift and both are still up an running over a year later. Mine has been used a ton of times and I have 5 batteries so it gets some heavy use. It's also the quadcopter I teach people on so it's had some nasty crashes.

These used tiny brushed motors which will easily burn out if the props are stuck against and object and you keep powering the props. This is simple to avoid, just cut power when you crash or if the quadcopter is stuck. This simple tip will make the quadcopter last a long time. After a year of abuse I'm finally replacing parts which was the result of a new pilot crashing and leaving the motors running when the copter was upside down. It's simple to take apart and fix. I removed the prop guards to save on weight and props are cheap to replace.

I opened the controller and extended the antenna as the built in cheap wire was just dangling inside. Range improved greatly with this simple mod.

The Camera is easy to remove, it's useful for pictures when you want them but it's a pretty weak camera so I usually fly without it.

This quadcopter is very lightweight and does not need to be registered with the FAA which is a bonus

title: Five Stars
text: Great drone

title: LOVE this drone but the camera is not anywhere near HD quality!
text: [[VIDEOID:bf880873a8165a07ed8622236b8ba2ce]] This little drone is awesome. It is light, portable, and very very easy to fly. I am completely new to drones or anything remote controlled and I can fly this thing easily indoors and outdoors. It can take a LOT of crashes too, especially with the prop guards on. The only problem it has while flying is that if it's windy this drone is so light that it will easily get pushed by the wind, and it also automatically drifts backwards because it is front weighted from the camera. So it can't just hover in the air, you constantly have to push it forward a tiny bit to keep it straight. I never really use it to hover though, so it's not really an issue for me. I got this to practice flying a drone and taking video, and I knew this camera wouldn't be good enough quality for actual photography so I have the x8c as well attached to a 4k action camera, but MAN the camera on this thing sucks. Again, I didn't have high expectations and I only use this for practice, but honestly. It says the camera on the x5c shoots in HD! It does not at all, the video is very grainy and dark. Also, the sounds of the drone flying is so loud that you can't hear anything in the video. I've shot video of my sister yelling into it and it just sounds like mumbling, you cannot distinguish words. Thats the only reason I gave it 4 instead of 5 stars, other than the crappy camera which is supposed to be "HD" this drone is awesome and I love it. Very easy to fly, user friendly, stands a lot of crashes, and just really fun!

title: This thing is all kinds of fun. I've flown it about a dozen times since ...
text:
This thing is all kinds of fun. I've flown it about a dozen times since receiving it and I keep wanting to fly.

Battery life is short, but that is to be expected from such a small capacity battery. I'd advise buying at least one extra to keep flying.

The range is fine for what it is really considered a toy. I've had it close to 100' up and have only had one signal issue. It was a brief loss but everything went right back to normal once the quad dropped a little.

The lights make figuring out which way you're pointing the camera pretty easy unless you're looking into the sun. In that case, you can't see anything. The controls are fairly smooth. I've not played with the loop buttons, but I'll probably get around to it sooner or later.

Take your time learning to fly if you have no RC experience. You'll wish you did if it winds up in a tree or on a roof. My flying skills are improving, but I swear I feel like this thing was attracted to trees at first.

I'd say this is a great stepping stone for those interested in a higher-end quad. Crash this one, not a $500 one.

It also came with spare props for when you break one or two.

title: Personally, the easiest quad I've ever flown.
text:
This thing is ridiculous. The power to weight ratio is absurd, I can be at two hundred feet in two seconds.

I've flown the tiny palm sized ones, I've flown the pizza box ones, and this is the perfect size. Not a fan of the camera, but what are you gonna do? Scotch tape a gopro to your x8c?

My 66 year old dad can fly it, my 5 year old niece can sit in my lap and "fly" it. Admittedly, she has an awesome five or six seconds when I let go, then she crashes it upside down into the lawn, but that doesn't do a thing to this chopper. It's light enough to hit softly, but powerful enough to get really freaking high.

Buy a couple extra sets of motors/blades/batts. It'll cost you fifteen to twenty bucks.

title: Pffft... It was good until it took off to some unknown place....
text:
My husband really loved his present and was having a great time with it until it got lost. The controller doesn't exactly control the drone like it's supposed to. The first time it disappeared, it shot out of our yard, across the road and up to the neighbors back yard three houses up (we live in a rural area, so we aren't exactly that close in proximity). The second time, it got stuck halfway up in a tree about 100 foot high (we managed to get it out by climbing). The third time, the controller wasn't responding well and the drone flew over the trees and past our next door neighbors house and we aren't even sure where it went from there because it was still going. He and our son looked for it several hours and gave up. It really needs a paging option so it can be located when things like this happens.
To make matters worse, the extra batteries I ordered for it had shipped the same day he lost it. I can't even get my money back for them because it cost more to send them back than what I paid for them. This whole experience just sucked in my opinion.

title: First one wouldn't sync...replacement is great
text:
When I saw the amount of good reviews on this drone, I knew I had to give it a shot. Unfortunately, the first one I got would not sync between the transmitter and the drone. I tried turning the transmitter on first, turning the drone on first, fast up-down on the transmitter, slow up-down, from a distance and up close, perfectly level surfaces such as table tops and counters, nothing. Read online that a few others experienced this and it turned out to be a problem with the transmitter. Returned the entire unit and got a replacement, synced up no problem.

I bought this as a gift for a friend, and while I have not been there to see all of the use, I was there for the initial flight and a couple others. For starters, the drone appeared to be exactly what I was expecting. Light, seemingly sturdy, and coming with all the tools to get it operating, minus 4 AA batteries for the transmitter.

The flight was surprisingly smooth, especially for myself and my friend who are both new to drones, and handled very smoothly indoors out of the wind. Took it outside and it did pretty well in some light wind, despite its weight. It did get carried away some times and occasionally blown into trees but I would chalk that up to user experience and wind interference.

Got a 6 pack of replacement batteries with a 6 battery charger and would highly recommend you do the same to get some quality time learning the drone without having to stop every 6-7 minutes to charge the single battery it comes with.

Have tried the camera, but couldn't remember how to properly operate it and didn't have the instructions at the time, so we ended up just taking still photos.

Would give this 3-1/2 stars due to the first not working and the instructions being written in a way that makes hardly any sense (probably some direct language translator that wasn't proof read by anyone that speaks English), but the new drone came quick and works so well that I'm bumping this up to 4 instead of down to 3.

title: I would recommend the extra batteries since one charge only last about ...

I would recommend the extra batteries since  one charge only last about 10 minutes. A bonus about the extra charger is he can charge the 4 batteries it comes with at the same time!

title: No micro SD card for camera nor size it manual.
text: received drone on time. Easy to fly. Really like this drone for beginners. The only negative is it did not come with a Micro SD card for the camera. There was an adapter for the SD card to USB but no card its self. The manual does not say what type to use with the camera. I had a 32gb but it does not work. I have ordered a 4gb micro SD in hopes that it is the right one. If this does not work I will be returning the drone. I will keep you posted.

title: I'm very surprised how good it is for for how cheap the price
text: I have a Mavic Pro and have been flying quads for a few years, RC helis and planes as well.  Got this on a whim when it was on sale, I'm very surprised how good it is for for how cheap the price.  It is what I'm recommending to my friends now if they want a beginner craft to try out drones.  I immediately took the camera off, since it doesn't transmit data to any screen.  Remember, this doesn't have GPS positioning, so it flys in ATTI mode (and will drift is there is wind, etc).  GPS drones like the Mavic are actually slightly easier to fly because the remain in one place when you let go of the sticks, but you're risking alot less money practicing with this one!!!!

title: Great for the price
text:
This quadcopter is great for the price since its fairly simple to fly indoor and outdoor and is able to capture photo and video. Ideal if you have kids wanting to try this out. It has the blade protection if it were to have small crash. The manual has some poor English, but its not hard to set it up and sync up with the remove (simply turn on the Transmitter first, then the Quad, wait for flashing light to slow down, and then throttle all the way up fast and then back down).

As other have said, you cannot rely on it giving a good quality video. Indoors, the video is poor due to lighting conditions and outdoors its better. Photos are poor as its only 2MP. Still, if this is your first quadcopter, then nothing is better. Once comfortable, will try the more expensive ones such as the DJI Phantom 4.

title: Good starter
text: It was fun for 2 days until it got stuck I the tree. Not the drone's fault of course :) Great beginner for a newbie.

title: Five Stars
text: User friendly

title: Wouldn't recommend
text: The X5C is just OK for the price, but with drone prices dropping daily, I wish I had chosen a different model with a GPS and better stability. My first flight ended up in a tree, so I decided not to fly it in even the slightest bit of wind (plus its winter) so I didn't fly again for a few weeks. 2nd through 4th flights went a little better, but found that anything above 30-40 feet, and the drone would drift a LOT, even when trimmed, and wouldn't follow instructions very well at all. My 5th flight attempt was a wash, as one of the motors was dead (see photo). Even though it was 10 days outside of the 30 day warranty, I emailed the company via their "help desk" link, hoping that after explaining that I had only flown it 4 times, they would honor the warranty. No such luck. Haven't heard back from them in over 2 weeks now. I ordered an Onagofly drone from indiegogo.com, and expect delivery in Feb or Mar, so I had purchased the X5C hoping to get some experience maneuvering a drone from the it, but I guess I'll just have to wing it when I get the new drone.

title: Only 7 minutes of flight time :/
text: Bought this as a father's day gift for my dad. He was ecstatic until we read the instructions which stated it only gets 7 minutes of flight per hour of charge. I didn't read that prior to purchasing so I did not get the extra batteries. We were disappointed with the flight time, but it is a good device. Handles fairly easy so it is a good beginner one for him. He will likely purchase a better one once he gets the hang of flying it, 7 minutes at a time.

title: I feel like a kid again!
text:
I received this yesterday. Prime shipping took about 4 days. The quadcoper arrived without damage via UPS. It's my first quadcopter and this thing is a blast to fly. It's a little smaller than I thought it would be but that's fine with me. Picture and video quality is okay, but I ordered an 808 camera to replace the one that's on it and will be making my own camera gimbal for stable footage. The memory card came with test pictures and videos on it from the factory it appears. I'm not sure if they were taken to test the SD card or if they were taken with the X5C itself. Picture quality tells me they took it with the drone.

This thing is plenty fast enough and is stable. I've flown nitro RC planes many years ago growing up, so it didn't take me long to get the hang of it. In low mode it's very friendly and easy to handle, and in high mode it's zippy and responsive. I was flying through my house and between doorways without any problem. Even did a few flips inside the house under an 8' ceiling! It seems to handle wind okay, but you wouldn't want to get it up too high on a gusty day. Once it's in the air it doesn't wont to come down. I took it out after dark and flew it with just the lights and it's easy to track.

One of the things I was worried about was if you could make slight adjustments while flying, and not just pushing the stick and it flys full speed one direction. Yes, you can make minor (slow) turns and adjustments for stable flight and videos as long as the wind permits.

If you're on the fence about this quad then you should take the leap. I was debating betweent this and the U818A, but decided to get this one as it looked like it would handle the wind better, and according to the reviews and my experience with the X5C it does. I ordered 4 extra batteries and ran all 5 of them through it (allowing a cool down period in between) without any issue. Replacement parts, such as blades and motors, are cheap too.

I may decide to get an even better camera later and film some wedding shots for others, or holiday shots with my wife for unique cards, etc.

title: it is a great toy/trainer that won't set you back too much if ...
text:
This is not a high end quad copter, but for the price, it is a great toy/trainer that won't set you back too much if you wreck it or lose it. The controls are responsive and easy to use, although the trim buttons don't seem to do much. It takes a lot of practice to be able to control it smoothly. The orange/green LEDs help you see orientation when you are pretty close, but farther away you will just have to go by feel.

The copter is very rugged for the light weight. I have crashed it into things and dropped it from the sky many times, and everything still works. It is all assembled with screws, making it easy to replace broken parts if you have them.

The camera is nothing to write home about (as you might expect), but you can get some okay video and stills if you fly it carefully while filming. I tried to use a 64gb card I had and the camera would not work, but it worked fine with the 4gb card it came with.

Battery life is good, about 10-15 minutes depending on the wind. I bought a 6 pack of batteries and a USB charger for them. With a USB 10000 mAh USB batter pack, I can keep them charging even while at the park. Changing the batteries is not super easy -- it is difficult to get the batteries seated, but manageable with some practice.

There is a newer version whose camera will broadcast video back to a smartphone app, so I would prefer that one over this one.

title: Great for a beginner- but horrible range- about 50 feet, or 16 meters...
text:
Gift for my 8yo little girl- great beginner quadcopter for the $$ spent. Very easy to fly indoors and outdoors (great in slight breezes). These things can take quite the beating, I am impressed with the robust design and blade guards. The 360 flip button is really cool, and easily flips front, back, left and right.
I would have given this a 5 star rating, but the range on these is terrible! After a few close range tests we ran some longer test runs, and much to my surprise after 50 feet the quad goes nuts, and locks on the last command given. If it happens to be "up" then kiss your new toy goodbye!
Hopefully she keeps it in range and it dosent get lost.
It did come with a mini SD card and reader, and we also purchased 4x batteries and a 4x charger which work out perfectly.
Great first "toy drone" but my 8yo will likely grow out of it in a month or two because of the disappointing short range.
B-

text: I bought this quad copter for practice before I bought a high dollar camera quad. title: Good starter drone,easy to work on.
text:
Great starter drone.

Now... if you are letting kids fly it... be sure to just go ahead and buy a "parts kit" that included new motors. They are def going to crash this a lot and ruin the motors. Its easy enough to take it apart and replace them. Don't bother wasting your time trying to solder new motors on the PCB... just clip the wires and splice them with electric tape. Soldering takes time and isn't really worth it considering they will probably ruin the morons again by crashing this thing while they have the motors running full blast.

Personally... this is more like an inside drone to me, or if its outside then just like 6-10 feet high and close to you. Sure... it can fly super super high, that is true. However, it is pretty light and wind ravages this thing out of control. If you let kids fly it outside and high, be prepared to go get it out of a tree or try to find it when it crash lands somewhere hundreds of yards away. I have about 500 acres of open fields behind my house, good for kids flying a kite on a string but not good for kids learning to fly a drone with no GPS or autopilot return, or head forward mode. They shoot this thing straight up, wind catches it then there is no fighting it... its not powerful enough and even full power again wind it will be blown away.

Replacing parts is easy. Batteries are Ok. I'm pretty sure the kit I bought came with 4 batteries, or maybe I ordered them separate. Anyways, a 4 way charger and extra batteries is needed for sure. I think its probably 10 min flying time, maybe 15.

title: The quad copter itself is fantastic its the controller and instructions that need improvement
text: The quad copter itself is fantastic its the controller and instructions that need improvement, its not really clear what buttons are affecting any adjustments in flight. So its more a trial and error. I would recommend indoor in a small safe area first to get the basic controls down before you tried to use this outdoors in a large area.

title: Excellent Beginner's Indoor/Outdoor 'Copter
text:
The X5C delivers stable, easy control and good quality pictures at an amazingly low price. In my experience so far, flight times are longer and charge times shorter than advertised. It is stable enough (and light enough) to be flown safely indoors. Direct sunlight, however, is required for good pictures. The camera is rigidly attached to the airframe, which results in rather shaky video. It records audio as well (mostly, the sound of the motors). It flies very well outdoors, but one has to be careful of wind, as the unit is liable to be blown away, especially if flown too high.
The only complaint I have is that the video switch is a toggle - press once to start recording, press again to stop. A small LED on the camera indicates video recording, but this is impossible to see from the ground in daylight. Thus, one can't quite be sure if one is recording or not. It would be nice to have a "recording" indicator on the control.
In general, the control is well thought out and easy to use. The user's guide is in the usual "Chinglish" and hard to figure out in places. The only assembly required is to attach the prop guards, which takes only a couple of minutes.

Unfortunately I was flying it high in the air and apparently it lost signal during a spin and it just continued to fly away in the spin. I tried running after it but it just kept going and disappeared behind some houses. I would probably buy another one though for inside use.

title: Great little r/c quadcopter for a affordable price.
text: This quadcopter so far has really been impressive! Ive only flown it 3 times since its arrival but so far it has already passed my expectations I made when I decided to buy a cheap $50 r/c quadcopter. I haven't had a single problem with its performance other than the cheap plastic used for the landing skids and blade protectors. So far they have surprisingly held up even after my first test flight but the skids partially broke at the white pegs that you insert into the copter for me and only due to user error and roughly landing on hard ground from high up. Luckily if you were already thinking about that during your purchase like I did you would have of most likely bought extra blades, blade protectors and skids for it, and the best part is you can get all that and extra motors for under 10 bucks in a package deal! Even with the partially broken skids i can still take off fly and land without further damaging them now that i have the hang of the throttle control. I gave 4 stars due to cheap plastic and the battery cover for being kinda difficult to open without fear of breaking it or the camera attached to it. Other than that it is more than worth its price I think and I recommend it to anyone who has little to no experience with flying r/c copters as the perfect starter/higher experienced r/c pilots. I will do a follow up review when it sees more flight time to say whether its still worth it or not but I don't see it changing my mind since the availability and price of replacement parts

text: [[VIDEOID:9c8c2c67fc41a4dfce162446b5166f70]] I always wanted a drone and was given one on my birthday buy my coworkers. I had it for 4 days and lost it due to extremely strong winds...in November. A storm last night (February 8th) blew it out of a tree to the ground. I charged the battery a little longer than usual and it worked perfectly. I think this speaks loads for the quality of the drone. I have used it twice today since finding it this morning and look forward to using it more. I've attached a video it took shortly before being taken by the windy sky.

He does say that it won't go super high without losing signal. He figured that out the hard way and it ended up crashing in our neighbors backyard. We didn't find it until the next day, but it was fine and it is still working great. Overall he is very happy with it's abilities and durability.

title: Great for the cost!
text:
My kids (7&10) love flying these. I lost one in a tree early on and got another to replace it. The first was in the tree exposed to winter elements for over a month...rain...snow...etc. It was knocked down by those February thunderstorms and shockingly it still works fine! We've had to super glue a broken rotor blade but given the abuse they get I'm pretty impressed for the cost!

Even better, it helped my son with a school assignment - He had to write a poem for school about an anxious situation using personification...this is what he came up with:

I lost my drone in a tree.
The branches laughed at me.
It was up there for a month.
The weather was a punch.
A thunderstorm knocked it out.
Then the branches started to pout.

LOL!

title: Great quad with 500 ft+ range!
text:
I've owned this quad for about 7 months and flown it for a total of maybe 50 hours or so. Overall, this is a great value and will provide hours of enjoyment. Some people have mentioned how the wind affects it, and in a 15-mph wind you'll likely have great difficulty controlling it. But I've found that moderate wind makes it more fun in some ways. For its weight, there is a LOT of body. The downside of that is how affected it is by the wind. But the upside of that is that if it ends up in a free-fall for any reason (battery dies, pilot error, hit by EMP wave, etc.) it will likely survive the fall if it lands on grass, trees, etc. It is super easy to fly on "normal" mode... give yourself about 4-5 flights to get the hang of it. On "high" mode it reacts much more drastically and will lean so much it may hit the ground if you're not careful.

Camera quality: Rather than simply give my opinion, I'd suggest doing a search for "X5C videos" and evaluate the video quality for yourself.

Flight duration: On average, about 7 minutes. And that's using the video camera about half the time.

Maximum range: A friend of mine and I tested this on his 500-ft long driveway. I was at the end of the driveway and the quad was still getting a signal back at the house. And no, I haven't done any of the range-boosting modifications. Depending on where you live you *might* pick up some interference from other signals. I've taken it straight up at maximum speed on a calm day for 60 seconds before it lost connection. At that height you can barely see this tiny quad so be careful! =)

Speed and Rate-of-climb: I would estimate around 20 mph and about 10 ft/sec. (you'll need to be on "high" mode - top left button toggles that function).

Durability: I took this quad about 500 feet high and let it free fall - it landed in the grass completely undamaged. One time my friend crashed it into my house at full throttle and that incident bent one of the propeller blades - I bent it back into place and it's been flying fine. Worst accident I had was when the wind caught it and it hit a neighbor's roof, then fell 2 stories down onto the pavement. That time it cracked a motor housing. I put some glue & tape on it and its performance hasn't been affected.

Tips: Once you get the hang of it, take off the propeller guards. And definitely buy at least 4 batteries with a 4-battery charger. As an added bonus, get a USB portable charger (around $15 on Amazon) to charge your batteries while you're in the field flying. Who wants to have to walk back inside to charge batteries? Fly safe!

title: One Star

title: Great beginner quadcopter
text:
This is an excellent quadcopter. It's very stable in flight, can move very quickly when you want it to, and has plenty of power. It looks very good, withstands multiple crashes well (I've had quite a few, not broken anything, yet...), and one of the best things is the spare parts are plentiful and cheap! Quite often you may find a quadcopter that seems like a great deal, but finding the spare parts may be exceedingly difficult. As well as quite often the parts quickly become obselete, and stop being manufactured. I've had several RC helicopters which after 6 months to a year, finding spare parts for became impossible.
This quadcopter comes with everything you need. Copter, controller, battery, and charger. The flight time is about standard, 7-10 minutes depending on how aggressively you fly it, and whether you have the camera attached or not. Great for beginners to learn how to fly. The remote has 2 settings, a low and high mode. The low makes the copter not move as fast, the controls gentler, perfect for close quarters or slower flying, and for learning to control the copter. High mode makes the copter respond aggressively to controls, for much quicker flight and handling, more suited for outdoors.
The only downsides I've found so far have been that the copter has around 50, up to 75 feet of control distance before it loses signal. And the instructions are horribly written in broken English, al,osteoporosis impossible to understand. But you can find plenty of info online from others.
I highly recommend buying a spare parts pack, and extra batteries with this, so you're not waiting forever for the battery to charge between flights, or for a new propeller to come in if you break one. Both can be found very cheap, 6 pack of batteries and charger about $20, spare parts pack with everything from 6 sets of blades to extra motors about $20.
Overall I highly recommend this copter!

title: If you think you broke it
text:
Great quadcopter for beginners to intermediate flyers.
But if you change the rotors!!!!! (Make sure you change them one at a time! They are directional and not the same. Each motor spins in a certain direction.)
So if you messed with the rotors and your quadcopter is not flying and falling over left or right or you feel air (thrust) being pushed up instead of down. Then you put the rotors in the wrong sequence.
Pictures will be posted soon!

title: Ton of Fun
text: Bought by my husband, Tom. This is his second quadcopter - the first (a different brand) died before he got good at it. That said, he should have bought this one first. We have had so much fun and so many laughs with this. My 74 year old husband is acting like he's 10. It is amazingly sturdy for being so inexpensive. We were very surprised by how good the video recording is - very sharp and good colors. The still photos not so much, but he didn't really buy it for the camera. The instructions do leave a little to the imagination. They have apparently been translated from the original language by someone who was not familiar with English - it helps to read them out loud to make more sense. That said, we have had 2 friends buy this model because we have been so pleased with it. Also, the company that supplies the copter and the spare parts kit is very interested in pleasing their customers and generating positive feedback.

title: Great introductory quadcopter.
text: As many reviewers before me have stated- this copter is worth every penny. This is a great machine for many reasons. After a week of use, about 20 flights (and about 40 crashes) this little quad has helped boost my flying confidence immensely.  I was a complete noob to RC copter flight, now I am a comfortable pilot even in mild winds.  This has been a great investment to learn to fly RC multi-copters.  Its fun and easy to fly, takes great pictures and video, its very stable hovering and is very responsive to commands.  I crashed this copter many times in some brutal ways and nothing has broken.  Flight time is very acceptable, but I would suggest 8 or more batteries and a couple extra chargers to keep the action going. Also- the red blades and guards help alot with orientation.  Oh, and don't forget to balance your props.

title: Great quad for learing to fly...
text: Nice quad, Everything worked on receipt. I need flying lessons. I have crashed many times and it still works. I put on the prop guards which helps with the crashes. I even ordered the Wifi camera and it works great with my Nexus Asus 7' tablet, but the cell phone mount doesn't fit. It is a GREAT quad to learn on.

title: So Fun!
text: I bought this for my husband last Christmas and we have really enjoyed it. The controls were very easy to work and calibration was easy. In no time we were outside flying. We got over-confident on our first flight and decided to fly it over a tall line of pines. The wind shifted and the drone sat down right onto the top of one of the trees. We were pretty bummed, but decided to wait a few days to see if we could locate it and possibly retrieve it before ordering another. Weeks passed and we had some terribly stormy/rainy nights, and we still had no luck finding it. So, I ordered another and the next morning we decided to go check once more and lo and behold, there is was. The wind had blown it down the previous night apparently. Luckily, my order hadn't shipped yet so I cancelled it. We let it sit for a few hours in case it was wet, re-charged the battery, and went out to try it. To our surpise, it worked perfectly. We have been more careful about flying on windy days, but we are pleased with this drone. The only thing I say is that if you are purchasing mainly for the video capabilities, you probably need to go another route. We have taken several videos and enjoy watching them, but the quality is not amazing. For us, this purchase was strictly for fun so it's not a big deal, but I did think it's worth mentioning.

title: Dream Drone
text: Dream Drone for learning how to fly this type of craft.. Mode 1 handles well for beginners, allowing for the unavoidable learning curve that will consist of multiple crashes. Rebounds well from even high altitudes drops and has a semi-auto rotate action that slows the impact with the ground. Camera takes decent pictures and videos. On a clear day and at the right altitude I've captured images of mountains and buildings that are 10-20 miles away. One curious thing is that Dragon Fly and Bumble Bee's are attracted to it in flight and almost seem to 'play' with it as it buzzes through the air.

title: Excellent for the price.
text: Excellent for the low price. You need to carefully adjust the trim inside the house before attempting to fly it outside. The instructions are obscure but you can figure them out. Take your time read them...follow them and you will find that you have a remarkable flyer for the money. Green lights to you, red away. This is a terrific buy.

title: I did not have expectations that this would be all that good a quadcopter
text:
I bought this on the Amazon treasure truck for $29, and feeling how light the box it came in was, I did not have expectations that this would be all that good a quadcopter. I am astonished at how great this thing is.

First the bad. It feels incredibly light and cheap. The battery only lasts 7 minutes, and the video resulting from the camera looks like a cell phone from 8 years ago. The instruction manual is written in Engrish. The remote has funny fake buttons to look more complex and futuristic than it is. Remote range seems to be about 200 feet or so, I'm estimating.

Now the good. I haven't handled a lot of quadcopters, but this thing handles pretty surprisingly smoothly. Within a day of use, I found I could easily fly this around my back yard, and confidently over water. I am continually shocked by how nimble and precise this thing handles. It really is a joy to fly, and immediately I had to buy the 6 battery pack so that I wouldn't have to wait.

Whatever factors it encounters, the quadcopter does a champion job of staying level. I lost one of the propeller guards after crashing it into a tree, and despite the lopsided weight, it doesn't seem to care. I have flown this thing in moderate winds, over turbulent temperature differences, and it barely fluctuates enough to be able to tell.

If you are thinking about getting into flying quadcopters, this is the one to start with, I'm amazed.

title: Great value, price vs. product, FUN.
text:
I bought this item as a gift for a 17-year old grandson but of course I had to try it out (Just to make sure that everything worked; wink! wink!) before giving it to him. I understood that for less than $50.00 the quality would not be that of a $1,500.00 drone so I was not terribly shocked when one of the green lens covers fell off during a bump on my roof while I was trying to figure out how to fly it. No Problem. I found the lens cover on the roof and just snapped it back into place. Perhaps it was not firmly snapped into place in the beginning. Perhaps it will never fall off again.

Everything worked properly as advertised right out of the box (after I charged up the battery). I found it VERY DIFFICULT to get the controller adjusted so that the drone would stay in place with all controls centered. In fact, I don't think I ever got the controller to adjust correctly for stationary hovering.

Much more could be said about learning to fly this unit AS A FIRST-TIME PILOT, but suffice it to say that for the price vs. product I personally feel that this is a VERY GOOD FIRST DRONE. I also purchased a pack of four extra batteries with charger so Ethan won't be limited to 5-7 minutes of fun between charges. In addition, I ordered the package of all spare parts for this unit for JUST IN CASE!

I am most likely going to buy another one for me to learn to fly so that when my grandson visits we can fly together on my 2 ½ acre property.

It's really too bad our corrupt government is going to make everyone register his or her drone!

title: So much fun!
text: We are having a blast with this. Camera works great. Perfect starter drone. My son and husband both have had a blast with this. Make sure to read instructions and go to a large open area. Great gift!

title: ... this for my son because it said it was great for beginners
text: Bought this for my son because it said it was great for beginners. It flies easy enough but when it gets out of range it seems to want to keep going. Very dangerous. There are no instructions included so be prepared to learn from YouTube. Learn how to calibrate first thing. I would not by this model again but I went with a cheaper Drone and that is what I got.

title: Good quality and great drone
text: Bought for my 8 year old son and he was able to fly it well within about an hour.  Good quality and great drone!

title: Great drone for the price
text: This drone is easy to fly, light weight, and will TAKE A BEATING! My child has crashed this thing into chairs, trees, the ceiling, the dog, and the ground from 45 feet up and it continues to work like a champ. The camera produces great quality shots. The batteries are a little short on life, but getting a few replacements means lots of flying time. I've been nothing but impressed with this little work horse. In fact, my other child received a defective one of these which we returned. We have been through two other drones as replacements. I finally re-purchased the Syma because of the durability and ease of control.

title: Cheap, low quality, not worth it!
text: Cheap, low quality, not worth the asking price.  Broken after 1 fly.  The fly wasn’t even that good spend more time balancing the little propellers so it would stop doing circles than actually flying it.

title: Perfect for New Pilots!!  MUST START HERE!!
text: This is the perfect quadcopter for learning how to fly!  You can literally let this quad fall out of the sky and it will continue to fly.  I have crashed this little quad hundreds of times and it still flies just as well as it did the day I unboxed it.  For me personally, I stripped it down to the bare frame... No Prop guards, No landing skids, No Camera, just the quad itself, the battery and the battery door, I'm seriously debating removing the door also, it's such a pain to get the battery in and out with that little plastic door on it.  This quadcopter has taught me enough so that I can fly FPV and more heavy duty 250mm racing class Mini-Quads.

title: Lots of fun

title: I really like Syma products
text: First of all, I really like Syma products.  They do a great job of providing a good product at a reasonable price.  As far as the X5C, it is a great quadcopter as far as handling, control, performance, etc.  The one thing I do not like about the X5C is that when the battery gets low the lights blink for about TWO SECONDS and then the unit shuts off!  If it's 50 ft. up in the air when this happens, it comes down right then!  I have the X5SW and the X8C Venture and they do not do this.  Both of these blink their lights to indicate low battery and then give more than ample time to bring them back in before they shut off.  I think this quick shut-off is a real problem with this unit.  Now I take a little digital timer with me and set it for a reasonable flight time, then bring the unit back in close to me for the rest of the flight because I know it's going to drop almost as soon as the lights start blinking.  I would advise spending the bit of extra money and getting the X5SW which does not have this quick shut-off problem.

title: Lots of fun

It is best to fly when there is no wind.  If it gets too high and the wind is blowing too hard it can take the copter away.

title: Although I enjoyed this Drone at first I noticed the flaws with ...
text: Although I enjoyed this Drone at first I noticed the flaws with it too. The controller appears to have buttons that have purpose but are just actually no more than decoration. The SD sim card on the drone for recording holds up to 8 gb which is fair, but it's complicated at first to understand how to actually record and take video with having a steady hand to do so without it taking off into space, losing control and it flying away into in my case a wild hillside.  Trying to find where it crashed to me was almost worth it because I was having fun... it being something affordable and different to master. Then I came to the conclusion that it's not worth my life with rattlesnakes, and mountain lions to say the least roaming behind my hillside.  Disappointing in truth of the battery lasting around a good 5 minutes with at least a 1.5 hour recharge. I credit the barrel roll that it can do, but my advise is do not fly it too high up, especially with a little wind because you will definitely lose it quickly.  Fun for beginners, but easy to lose.  I credit its durability surviving the few crashes I had to enjoy it with. If your willing to spend fifty bucks, I suggest you play a little more for one with GPS. Otherwise you will might regret it like me. It's extremely easy to lose control with this one.

title: Thanks to all the good comments and feedback
text:
I bought this as a birthday present for my husband. Because I knew nothing about drones and he was interested in something appropriate for a beginning hobbyist, I relied very heavily on the Amazon Best-Seller tag and the reviewer comments to choose this product. I have to say that everyone's comments were spot-on and I give all the other reviewers all my heartiest thanks. Thanks to all the good comments and feedback, I feel that we made a very good choice.

Out of the box it felt flimsy to me, but appearances are deceptive. It certainly has been durable and has held up to numerous crashes during the learning-to-fly process. Sure enough, as many others reported, our first time outside it wound up about 15 feet in the air stuck in a tree. He was eventually able to knock it down, and it survived that fall unscathed. I had bought the extra propeller blades as insurance, but I'm starting to think he won't need them.

Someone had advised buying the extra batteries because the one included battery lasts for only 7 minutes. This was great advice. Husband reports actually getting around 7-8 minutes. The extra batteries keep him flying without waiting while a replacement is charging.

Husband gives it two thumbs up.

title: My husband really enjoyed getting this as a Christmas gift

title: Great price and fun to fly.
text:
Great fun! Understand what you're getting for the price. The battery life estimate of 7 minutes is pretty accurate. Be aware that this is very lightweight and the wind will take it on you quickly if you're not paying attention. The fine adjustments aren't so great but once you get the hang of it, it's very easy to fly. The prop guards will pop off easily but that didn't bother me considering the price. The vid camera is decent and you can have longer videos if you buy a micro sdhc card with more storage. I was surprised that it records audio as well as video but it's mostly the drone props you hear.

I'll be buying more batteries for this. I set a timer at 6 minutes so that when it goes off I bring the drone down or away from anything I don't want it to crash on when the battery expires. When the battery is discharged there's not much warning. The lights start flashing and it drops uncontrolled. The props continue to spin so it's a "controlled" crash. Fly it in an open area away from obstacles until you get the hang of it.

Love it. I'd buy it again and recommend it for a starter to anyone.

title: It gets harder as they get older trying to find things they would like. They were completely surprised and loved them

title: Read the instructions ...
text: Very happy. Having never flown a quad copter before I had trouble at first but that way mainly because I skimmed over the the instructions and went straight to flying (and crashing). Then a friend came over and showed me how to set the initial horizontal calibration, put it in slow mode and adjust the trim for level flight (all things that were explained in the instructions). Now after only 2-3 more sessions, I am able to hover around my living room, turn and bank without hitting anything and land it more of less where I want it to. We did use the camera a few times when my friend was flying, the rotor noise masks the audio but the video is not bad, all things considered.

title: Fun, very promising, but camera never worked and sadly lost a gear in a crash on the 3rd battery charge's run.
text:
Got it very, very quickly. Nice! Parts apparently take forever to get. Ouch. Ouch. Ouch.

First drone for me.

Suggestion for the manufacturer: At a local backpacking hotel, find someone to clean up the manual. Pay by shipping a bunch of units with spare parts to the person's family and friends. A win all around.

Suggestion for manual: Parts pictures show motor and blade orientation wrong. Makes it hard to know which motors are clockwise, and which counter-clockwise. Both pictures are not consistent with logo and unit/camera/battery orientation.

Trial and error made most things clear. The manual was only needed to explain camera operation. (And flip and mode control - never used - unwanted.) Suggestion: Change camera control switch so it doesn't look like a trim tab. And stamp indicators on it to show what it does. A red video "recording" light would be a good spiff, too. Unfortunately, my camera was DOA.

Learning to fly: It was fun to fly. Learning curve was fast. The unit is built from light, springy plastic. Great for crashing! Also, the built-in, motor-kill-on-crash feature is a godsend. I crashed it every flight, indoors, but was getting the hang of it when, on the 3rd battery charge, a crash left a tiny gear lost forever. Looks like a replacement takes a month to get here. But, given the dead camera, maybe it's best to reject the whole unit and try again.

Do not know about transmitter range. But if it's the reported 100 feet, then suggest that be extended on the next product rev. 100 feet doesn't get above the trees in Seattle area.

Not absolutely sure the trim tabs work at all. A bit subtle, they are.

Flight control thought/suggestion: To compensate for the drop in lift, it might be interesting to auto-adjust the power when navigating.

Bottom line: Fun few moments, but not worth 50 bucks 'cause of the lost gear after just a few minutes of flying. We'll see what happens when the parts come in. Or, heck. maybe it's best to reject the unit on camera grounds and try again.

Advice to others with no drone experience: Yes, the experienced guys are right about getting a cheap "toy" like this to learn to fly. First flying is crash city. And, get a gob of batteries. If you figure to play for an hour, you'll want a dozen. Which means you'll need a lot of USB charging ports and cables to juice them.

Update:

Sent the unit with the bad camera back. Could not figure out how to just return the camera, nor a way to make good that I had lost the little gear.

Ordered another unit.

It came quickly. And, the next day an already-ordered pack of 4 batteries come in.

The new quad's camera works. Movies are reasonably clear for a cheap camera. The only way to see if it's taking movies is an obscure red light inside the camera housing. If you let the battery die without stopping video recording, you may get no movie. Figure around 2 megabytes per second, so the 4G card is good for over a half hour.

Could not find the limits to the controller's range. The quad went out of sight down the driveway while still under control. 100, 150 feet away, at the least. Beyond earshot.

Lost a motor. It went bad in stages. Ran thru all 5 batteries before the motor was no longer operable. Now to wait a month for a pack of motors.

No change to the review bottom line because of the bad motor. It appears this device really needs a lot of spare parts on hand. That parts are replaceable is remarkable, though, for a throw-away type toy. That they take so long to get is the unit's biggest downside.

title: My daughter and I love playing with it

The connection between the transmitter/ controller was not very accurate and one could very quickly lose control through either wind or going out of signal range. title: Cheap and China made.
text: I flew this once and was great then went to charge the battery and the battery would not charge. Am in the process of returning and will not buy again.

title: A pleasure to fly
text:
I bought 4 additional battery pack and was able to learn how to fly quickly. There are two different flying modes which I found helpful. Mode 1 is Up/Down/Move Left/Move Right on the right stick. Mode 2 is UP/DOWN/TURN LEFT/TURN RIGHT on the left stick. Coming from flying exclusively airplanes I found Mode 2 a good way to break in to flying a quad. Once I was more confident I was able to switch to Mode 1 and now I am able to fly where I want to after about 2 hours of flight time. Handles a moderate breeze well and can deal with a lot of crash landings on grass without damage.
The camera footage is not great but what do you expect for a $40 aircraft. I was able to inspect the shingles on my roof by flying over and the camera is in focus with good color and decent resolution. HOWEVER 700mb for a 6 minute video is a bit excessive. I would recommend using free HandBrake video transcoder to save space if you are going to keep the videos.

title: Very disappointing. Do Not Waste Your Money On This
text:
Very disappointing. I had the drone less then 1 week. The drone was really cool to fly, then 1 of the propellers stopped working. I've researched the issue and it says most likely its a motor. 2 Motors cost about $10 plus shipping. You have to have a Soldering Iron to replace the motor which is a additional cost. Thats another $20-$30. To me seems like to much work for a $30 drone.

I was never able to get the camera to sync with my phone. I tried going to places that had limited cell service to see if something was in the way. Never could get it to work.

Do yourself a favor and buy a better racing drone that is better quality. Might cost you in the long run but they are better quality.

title: Agile, durable and oh so much fun!
text:
I initially purchased the Syma X5C to practice flying and avoid crashing my Phantom 3 not expecting to fall in love with it. This quad is amazingly agile, fast and unbelievably durable. The first couple hours with the drone went like this: crash, wince, dust off and fly again.

I first considered the lack of a headless mode a disadvantage as I'd gotten accustomed to my former Parrot drone's "absolute control" feature. I now realize it was a blessing as I can now control my Phantom regardless of the direction it is facing from the muscle memory garnered using the Syma.

The only negative points are the charger is subpar and the incredibly light frame of the aircraft makes it prone to drifting in light breezes. Oh amd the camera/battery cover is a bit flimsy and can come undone with slight impact. Other than that, I can honestly say I have never had so much fun for such a small monetary investment.

Post Script: this quad is so enjoyable to fly that agyer only two sessions my wife decided to buy a quad herself.

title: Excellent for the price!
text:
I got my son one of these for Christmas and ended up with one myself. I've been practicing with mine and have gotten better at flying it (it does take practice). My son hasn't flown his nearly as much and yesterday saw me flying mine up high and he decided to try and see how high he could fly his.

Before I could stop him it drifted into the tallest nearby tree-about 40 feet up. The only thing I could get that high was to try and knock it out with a pellet gun. Several unsuccessful shots through the body later we tag teamed and he hit the throttle and I shot- our first try together we got it falling out of the tree, hitting lots of branches on its way down.

All of that to say this-despite the holes shot through it and despite falling out of the tree and crashing down this copter still flies. I have crashed mine in some pretty ridiculous ways, too, and it just keeps on flying. It is good to note that the controllers sync to a copter so you can fly multiple copters at one in the same area.

A more technical evaluation: The copter is light, and flying it outdoors is a challenge even with minimal wind. The stabilization is pretty good but it doesn't auto hover or anything fancy so don't expect it to fly itself. That's also a good thing in a way-you are more in control, kind of like driving a manual instead of an automatic.

The flight time was what I saw in other reviews at about 7-8 minutes. I very soon after bought a set of 700mAh batteries that are more responsive and fly longer. In my case I bought a five pack with a five port charger so I can usually fly as long as my free time to fly lasts (or longer and I have to go without getting to use all the batteries).

Today I finally tried out the 360 roll feature and it worked very well. It loses a lot of altitude so you need to make sure you are high enough to execute it or maybe I need to just be harder on the throttle (it could certainly be user error).

There is a huge difference between the two performance modes and now that I'm somewhat more comfortable with flying it I really enjoy the faster controls.

The photos and videos aren't fantastic but are acceptable. I had no idea the video had sound, too, but it's kind of pointless because it how much prop noise the mic picks up.

Only cons (at this price point) would be the difficulty to fly outdoors and that it can need some fiddling with the on center adjustments to keep it flying true so that it responds to controls predictably.

I have also ordered some three blade props to see if they make it even more responsive and handle even better.

For the price it seems like it would be hard to find anything better-it is an accurate, EXTREMELY durable quad copter that is fun, agile and with it's two power profiles it is good for beginners and to grow with. It certainly isn't anything super fancy needing virtual reality goggles to pilot or anything but for what it is I am very, very pleased.

title: Fun Fun Fun
text:
The Syma X5C quadcopter was exactly what I needed. I learned to control it. Then took it high. Winds have fun with this little guy, but as long as I remembered which way was which, I was able to fight through the wind. I had tons of fun.

The bad-- I got this guy stuck in the top of my 50' tree. I had to climb up about 15 foot and use 3 lengths of 10ft pvc to barely knock it down through the branches. Minimal physical damage, but i burnt out one motor trying to get it out of the tree without climbing.

The good-- four motors on the way for less than $10. I will have spares for the next time

title: Great starter quad
text: I'm what I'd consider comfortable with RC, I've run dirt buggies and road cars for years, but new to anything that flies. I did a fair amount of research and nearly everyone said the Syma X5 series was the place to start with quads.  I agree 100%, this so far is a durable and easy to fly learner quad.  I'd recommend to anyone curious about quads but looking for a little better experience than what you get out of the toy aisle.  As noted by various reviews this is a really light quad for it's size so while it works well outdoors, it does get pushed around quite a bit in the wind.  Anything other than a light breeze wouldn't really be recommended.  I did crash a couple of times but mostly because of my own inexperience.  The included extra props come in very handy but if you're learning I'd suggest getting more to have on hand.  Extra batteries will also add to flight time and overall enjoyment.  The camera is OK but the angle is a little weird, there are several videos online that show how to modify it for a more "head on" view though.

title: These fly really nice if you can get one that isn't defective out ...

If I had 2 more hands I'd video the issue.  These fly really nice if you can get one that isn't defective out of the box. Or missing parts. I already returned Syma X5CW due to defective camera that wouldn't connect to the AP and a motor that quit after 15 flights and hit the ground.  I'm an experienced flyer for 15 years radio controlled coppers, planes, gliders etc .al  and I'd like to get a smaller Quad to enjoy. Maybe I'll get a non defective one next time around.

text:

I shop on Amazon a lot, and have for a few years, I have never had a problem with any product until now. I was surprised to see that the tape on the box looked tampered with. When we opened the box and checked the products inside it was clear that this was an open box sale. It appears that the drone was returned but no one checked it before throwing it back on the shelf. We flew the drown and checked the camera for any problems, we have not yet noticed anything wrong with the drone so we have kept it so far. A word to Amazon if your going to sell an open box item you should let the consumer know, as they believe they are purchasing a NEW product. An open box discount should apply as well. This was a gift.

title: I will buy more as these wear out. - Outstanding!
text:
This has to be one of the best toys I have ever had. I am over 60 so I have had lots of toys.
I bought two of the Syma X5Cs. No problems with hundreds of flights on them. They fly very smooth and fast. I would estimate about 150 to 200 feet straight up. The reason I have two is so that I can alternate between them so the motors can cool off between flights. With 9 batteries it is easy to fly for over an hour at a time.
These were my first quad copters, so they have many wrecks and so far no real damage. I burned up one motor, that was my fault for leaving the throtle stick on when it was upside down after a crash.
If you remove the prop guards, camera and battery cover and fly in expert mode you can easily fly in 8-10 mph winds, I have flown in higher winds but they are too light for that..
I would recommend taking it apart (about 26 tiny screws) and moving the battery connector to the under side (route the wires through the battery compartment). You will be able to make a much better connection to the battery. I have connected my batteries hundreds of times with no problem. Before the mod, my batteries wouldn't always make a good connection..
The camera is not great, but what do you expect for less than $60, it works if you have an understanding of computers and the importance of closing files.
Buy the $6 spare parts kit with 4 motors and you will get ton's of flights on these.

Happened to me - disappeared in my neighborhood, but fortunately some kind neighbors took the time to watch the video on the SD card and figured out who owned it. Instructions are written in Chingrish, and are pretty useless. Still trying to figure out how to get it into Mode 2 where I THINK it is more responsive (advanced for expert fliers). This thing has been repeatedly dropped to the ground and run into houses, fences, people, etch and the only thing that has ever happened was to break one of the struts that protects a blade. A little bit of scotch tape fixed that right away!

title: Boyfriend loved it! He did get it stuck in a ...
text: Boyfriend loved it! He did get it stuck in a big tree on day #2 of use, but he was able to get it down, luckily.

title: ... negative reviews on this quad but I am really happy with it
text:
I know there are a lot of negative reviews on this quad but I am really happy with it. Yes it does not have great range, but you can do a Google search to find several videos on how to modify the antenna. Be careful! On one of the videos I watched someone use heat-shrink on a solder joint with a heat gun. I did this and fried my controller and had to order another one. If you do it, shrink it with a soldering iron. Once I got my new generic controller the video doesn't work.

I still love this quad because it does very well in the wind. I have seen other reviews that it does not, but that was probably when the controller was set on low speed. On high it will cut right through the wind. On low it just kind of hovers in one place.

I would recommend to anyone buying this to buy some extra skids and other accessories such as batteries. THE BATTERIES ONLY LAST ABOUT 7 MINUTES. Some of the reviews knock that, but it even says it in the product description.

All in all this is a really fun quad to fly with the 360 degree "Eversion" (as they call it) feature. I would recommend this quad to anyone who wants to buy an inexpensive entry-level quad

title: Great to learn on, but do not push it
text:
Fun little toy, but you get what you pay for. Lasted a week with heavy usage. Control is simple to learn but hard to master.

Replaced motors, which isnt hard if you can solder. Remember to keep track of screws if you are doing repairs. Remember to replace batteries in transmitter too, or you'll lose signal if it goes too high, and WILL NOT be able to control descent.

Remember that this is a toy, and that it can break easily if used outside around hard surfaces. One fall from 30 feet onto concrete and it's done for. Play with it inside, or around soft surfaces with little wind while outside.

title: Best $50 I've spent on anything ever!

Best $50 I have spent on anything. Out of the box synched to transmitter and lift off in my living room. Was almost perfectly trimmed from the very beginning. What other RC can you do multiple flips in a living room and not hit anything?? Camera is good. I wasn't expecting HD so there was no disappointment. I was pleasantly surprised at how well it did in low light. I brought it to work....flew for about 15 seconds and a buddy got on his phone and ordered one. I would recommend getting the 4 extra batteries with charger....Flight time is about average at about 7 minutes and it stinks waiting 30-40 minutes to fly again with just one.

Syma always delivers.

text: Keep thinking I need to order another for all the crashes and trees I've encountered.  But no need.  Good gift idea .

title: My First Drone
text:
Been tempted to get a drone for awhile now. Saw a coupon code for this guy and decided now was the time to strike. I have never flown a drone before or had any tips on what to do. I just charged it up and gave it a shot. Here are my impressions after 1.5 batteries worth of flying. First .5 was in my front yard night I got it, second attempt was full battery charge the next day in an open`ish field down my street.

- It's hard to fly, easy to get up, hard to control
- I thought the battery connection was broke, but you just have to use muscle to "snap" it in. (It feels cheap and I was afraid to use muscle to pop it in)
- It survives light crashes with ease. One of the green plastic covers over LED light did disappear during my full flight today.
- The little camera had a 8 gig micro SD card with it, also came with the thingy you can put that in so your computer can read it.
- I think it will take a good while to learn how to fly it
- Do not let your young kiddos try it, unless you have looooooooooots of room. My 7 year old was begging and I let him try it, lasted like 2 seconds.
- The camera has audio as well, mainly hear the blades whirling and your crashes.
- Well worth $30.00

title: Great beginner drone!
text: For the price, I think this is a great beginning drone. We flew it inside, and it was pretty stable. Of course, we crashed it a few times, and it held up really well. Only con is battery life, but we are ordering a battery. The one that comes with only lasts about 10 min. Would recommend!

Mine came with a 4gb card instead of 2gb for some reason. Also, without all the gear on, I've seen 10 minute flight times. So, it's all about how you fly it I guess!

Needless to say a drone needs all propellers running to work.
Waste of money and then more money , but more than the money it's the dissapointment of my grand babys is what matters most.

I bought this quad-copter not expecting much. To my surprise, I quickly became hooked. While it took a little time to figure out how to fly it and get comfortable with it, I am now absolutely addicted and can't seem to put this thing down.

The X5C is extremely resilient to crashes and fairly easy to fly. I would definitely recommend purchasing some additional upgraded batteries, because you're not going to want to put this thing down.

The remote has really good range, and the props can take all sorts of beating.  I haven't had to use the spare props that came with it yet.  Highly recommend.

title: ... to see if I would want to purchase a better drone in the future
text: I purchased this to see if I would want to purchase a better drone in the future. While the flight time is a bit short, this is a good way to test to see if having a drone is for you. The camera produces decent images and it is fairly easy to learn how to fly. Good value for the money.

title: Great value, impressive performance.
text:
Very fun and affordable flier for anyone to learn on. The camera quality is OK, it does the job but isn't very impressive. You will want to buy extra batteries to extend your enjoyment. Batteries take about an hour to charge and at best you'll get six minutes of flying time. You can buy slightly higher MAH batteries for longer flight times. I bought extra props but haven't broken one yet, and I've crashed it many times. It doesn't fly well in the wind, which is to be expected for most quad copters in this class.

I would recommend it for anyone wanting to start with quad copters, experienced pilots, or someone looking for a fun toy for a child (or husband!). Don't waste your money on Air Hogs.

title: Great copter for the price, but the blade guards are a problem
text:
My first copter - and quite awesome it is. However, it suffers from a glaring design flaw: the blade guards have an awful tendency to snag on tree branches and just.. stay there.

I've managed to rescue it from tree branches twice on the first day I used it and it required a heroic effort. The third tree, however, was sadly beyond my reach. Goodbye, Syma X5C. You were gone too soon.

So, if you want to take your copter outside - do it without the blade guards.

text: Great inexpensive quad to learn on. But the brushed motors are not very good at all. I am on my third set of motors already. One to two motors burn out at a time.

title: I love this amazing drone.
text: I just love this drone, I fly it around my house at amazing speeds, I fly it up to the walls flat out and then pull back at the last minute, amazing maneuverability. It gets tossed about in heavy winds when flying outdoors as its very light, so wait for the wind to die down a bit before flying. This awesome engineering marvel will bring you loads of fun, and give you the necessary training should you decide to get a pro drone. Make sure you buy some extra batteries as you will not want to put this baby down. The video quality is not up to scratch but for US$60 for the entire package, it will be the best bit of money you will ever spend. I had to change one of the motors but at less than US$10 for 4 motors plus props, it didn't even matter. Syma, you guys made a super flying machine here, kudos.

title: Motors do not last
text:
I purchased this quad copter about a month ago and within 30 flights, one of the motors has already stopped working. I usually fly the quad copter at 1/2 to 3/4 power on the advanced setting for the 5 to 7 minute flight time a battery has. The motor has never been damaged in any way, but after a few flights, one or more of the motors stop spinning and the quad copter is useless. I have dissembled the quad copter and discovered the motors are hard wired in and not replaceable. If they had been replaceable, this would be a 5 star rating. After spending $50 on the copter, 20 on replacement batteries to have the device fail in under 30 days is very frustrating.

Pros:
2 flight modes
programmed flips
improved gyro stabilizers

Cons:
Short life span
poor quality motors
Motors are not replaceable
Extremely over priced for the quality
The auto gyro fails at times and the copter cant take off
